review_title: Very mixed bag, many members of senior management highly dysfunctional and low EQ. (LCD Division)
pros: Good job stability given global positioning and portfolio scope. Perhaps good place to cut your teeth out of college, but don’t be afraid to look for “greener pastures” at the two year mark. Some direct report managers are good, but many are hit or miss in my experience.
cons:
Low follow through on commitments from senior management and periodic manipulation with comp plans to the reps detriment. Generally poor ethics. Given size, leadership can shift very quickly whether sales territory, role, product or account mix. Features a high change environment and many shifting expectations over time.
Advice to Management
When printing criteria for sales rep awards have the integrity to follow through on those same published commitments.

review_title: Good in ruining career and life of freshers
pros:
1. Job timings are good.
2. You will get salary before time.
cons:
1. After appointing as fresher they will make you work however they want. Even if you want to work as developer not automation engineer..it doesn't matter to them.
2. Mentors will treat you nothing. Humiliate you in every meeting and don't help or reply to messages.
3. You need to get permission for everything you do in daily basis and mentors won't reply.
4. Will shout on juniors in public.
4. Team members seeing your condition, try to take advantage of you in any way they want. They are good in manipulating the mind of new comers.

Don't ruin people's life. New comers are also people. Also see in what field other person want to work.
In other companies if some one shouts or talk regarding the personal things which are outside boundaries..it is considered as offence and they are punished by law.
If some one is more experienced doesn't mean he is god and other is useless.
Don't give opportunity to people when they are asking to leaving the organization.
On the last days I discussed this with a HR and see said it's your mistake you should have told earlier.

Repor

pros: It’s hard to balance family life and work load
cons:
I worked for Thermo Fisher for three years and my experience at this company was life stripping, dreadful, unpleasant, and very inconvenient. The way you are treated really depends on your management. In this job as a black male people have a tendency to control you, manipulate you, and overwork you. I applied for a senior scientist position and Thermo Fisher was really about sales at that time so my position wasn’t really what it was suppose to be. I worked mostly on sales, and really all Thermo Fisher cares about is sales. If you are looking for a job that is involving science this job will not be suitable for you, they stripped away science from me and I really felt like a technician and sales man. During this terrible time in the pandemic, Thermo had no pardon. I was overworked and was not able to balance my work life with my life outside of work, I was barely able to spend time with family, I felt as if I was pulled away from life. When I decided to leave the company for my own good, I gave a two week notice to my boss because I found a more suitable job for me. I called my boss to let him know that I’m resigning and gave him a two week notice. That very same day after the call, my boss terminated me and his reasoning was that I “did not disclose the company I’m going to”. They terminated without even allowing me to have an exit interview with Thermo Fisher Human Resources to know the reason I’m resigning. That shows you that the culture at Thermo Fisher is beneath employment standard. I’ve come on campus many times to train people on how to use bioreacters and different techniques and as a black male was looked down upon and had no support from my management team. I do not recommend this to anyone who wants to work in the science field and wants to balance family life with work life.
Advice to Management
Management needs to be trained on on how to manage employment

review_title: Somewhere to develop bad habits, and bad mental health.
pros: If you're looking for somewhere to cruise along through your career with little oversight as a means of retiring with a decent retirement package, look no further.
cons:
If you're looking for somewhere to learn and develop good habits as a lean manufacturing engineer focused on continuous improvement, this is NOT the place for you. Be prepared to fight fires like never before. Be prepared for management and executive leadership to make uninformed decisions from an ivory tower. Be prepared to have little or no direction with project work. And lastly, be prepared for a barrage of negativity from all directions. The culture, particularly in production, is extremely toxic. While the associates are, for the most part, pleasant folks, the challenges they face every day just to do their jobs brings most of them down to a place of toxic negativity that spreads like a cancer. Do not be misled by the fact that this is a "Thermo Fisher Scientific" plant. There is very little science to be found here. Other plants within the division refer to this plant as 'the wild west.'
Advice to Management
There likely needs to be a major overhaul of the current management structure if any tangible change is going to take place. The current management team is like the popular group in high school. They're a tight clique and everyone else is on the outside, including when it comes to making decisions that affect the plant.

and cons…mostly cons

Business Outlook

pros: Decent pay, 401(k), nothing else
cons:
- Highly political. All that matters is who you impress. Leadership is incredibly obsessed with optics. It’s all dog and pony. The CFO is only focused on the most superficial items (when he’s not talking about himself) and never focuses on work, knowledge and quality.
- Far too many incompetent employees. Honestly, I don’t think 20% of the Finance staff have a clue what they are doing. They are constantly makes mistakes.
- You are always fixing someone’s mistakes and they keep making them. You would almost think it was their job to make mistakes.
- Leadership plays favorites and they aren’t subtle about it. I’ve seen people ignore emails, make major mistakes, lie, but as long as they parrot the cliche business jargon and brown nose, they are leadership’s favorite.
- Did I already mention leadership’s uselessness? All they do is set up meetings to book up their calendars and look busy.
- Lazy, lazy, lazy staff. I think I can count on one hand the number of people who I’ve worked with who were not lazy.
- I hope you enjoy tire tracks because you will be thrown under the bus a lot. And they plan on running you over.
- Your hard work and efficiencies will not be appreciated. All they will do is give you someone else’s work, while that person does close to nothing.
- Incredibly superficial. They will thank a highly compensated consultant for doing next to nothing but not say a word when you worked all night to meet a deadline.
- Unfortunately, most companies are just as bad.

pros: The pay is decent and the work/ life balance is good
cons:
IT and HR are nonexistent. I have had so many issues that just get brushed off and never resolved.
The sick time/ vacation time gets all piled together, so I have 2 weeks total that I can take off, so it’s a risk to take vacation time incase you need that extra time for if you get sick. 
The culture at my specific location is incredibly toxic and cliquey, I feel as though I don’t fit in. 
Management is a joke, there is no QC manager to run the department. Just a few supervisors who are in way over their head. 
There are not enough people in the group
Advice to Management
Hire more people, hire a manager. The current system isn’t working. Also we are all adults, it’s okay for people to become friends at work, but for cliques to form is another issue. Get it together

review_title: Fast pace company with a lot of improvement needed
pros:
- Very fast pace company with good products
- Playing a huge role in fighting Covid-19
cons:
- Does not promote within, always look for external candidate
- Middle management has the toughest job of hitting target and trying to engage the team
- High turnovers
- Senior leadership makes structure changes that affect teams. Leaving internal teams to manage changes that creates to friction
Advice to Management
- Evaluate promotion criteria, how can a manager who has a smaller team and revenue be a senior manager to someone who has higher revenue and bigger team
- Appointment of roles based in capability, not one relationship with their immediate superior
- There are local capable people within country, you don’t have to bring another person from another nationality for the role especially culture and how business conducted is different in this region
- Do risk management when there are structural changes so teams can communicated and aligned properly on the rules of engagement

review_title: They should pay for therapy after working there.
cons:
ltant/Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Opportunity to do meaningful work. Science is cool. Opportunity to work with very intelligent people. Good benefits. The coworkers were great.
Cons
Lack of transparency in management. Siloing. Very little opportunity for advancement. Lack of inclusion. Lack of real support for innovators. Hostile/toxic conditions.
Advice to Management
More skip level meetings. Upper management needs a real picture of what is happening at producer level. Take issues reported through HR seriously. Find out who actually are key employees and do what is needed to retain them. Lower level managers can do great harm, train them better.

pros:
Lots of growth in the company.
Colleagues are very personable and for the most part great to work with.
Lower management supports their subordinates both internally and externally.
Work with all sorts of different clients (small to large pharma).
Opportunities to gain a lot of experience in the industry.
cons:
Business seems to come first over worker wellbeing and quality of work.
Site leadership will promise the world to the clients at the expense of the people who actually do the work.
Work week is at a minimum 45-50 hours without paid overtime or time in lieu.
Extremely high turnover.
Manufacturing supervision and management (especially in USP) needs more experience.
Advice to Management
Stop overpromising to clients and expecting us to deliver a top-notch product with a truncated timeline. Do this and you'll see a far lower turnover rate.

review_title: If I Could Give Less Than 1 Star I Would
pros: The only pro I can come up with is that I have met a few good friends while suffering through working here.
cons:
This company does not care about it's employees. They constantly send out emails stating how many millions of dollars in profits they are making but then treat their employees with zero respect. If you like being over worked, having no work home life balance, being poorly paid, having awful medical coverage and not having basic amenities on site then this is the place for you. They spend too much time hiring managers and having no workers to do the actual work. Every process that cooperate "improves" makes it harder and harder to get your work done. Its disgusting that a company making so much money can't even get their employees decent medical coverage. I still spent over $10,000 out of pocket last year on medical bills because the horrible insurance they have covers nothing. Women are treated like second class citizens at this company. They have so little respect for us that they can't even put feminine product disposal bins in the bathroom stalls. The toilet water sprays all over the toilet in the women's bathroom. It's disgusting. If you move up in the company they don't pay you fair wages for the job that you are doing, but they have no problems hiring people in off the street (at a lower level than you are) for more money. They cut off access to entrances to buildings with no warning so you then have to walk over half a mile around the entire plant to get to another entrance (all while in debilitating pain because you can't afford anymore medical bills). You are forced to work well over 40 hours a week and weekends with no overtime. This company does not care about anything other than it's own profits. They will take every short cut they can to get there. They have useless groups at this plant like security and HR, who never do their job and pass everything off onto someone else so nothing is ever resolved. They can't even put up decent cameras in the parking lot so when some hits your car and drives off there is nothing you can do but get stuck with another bill you can' afford because they pay you so little. Last year we lost 19 out of 32 people in our group. But the company does not care. They hardly even replace them. They just pass off more work to others and keep burning them out too. People are sick of being over worked and not respected by this company. Run do not walk as far away from this company as you possibly can.
Advice to Management
Stop playing the politics game and actually do something for your employees and group. Management is full of false promises and no action.

pros:
The company culture, working environment and colleagues here are very good and healthy which are the key factors to make me continuing to contribute in this organization.

On top of this, there is always career advancement opportunities provided to employees in term of exploring diversified functional team, as long as you are willing to take up the challenges. And, there are always ready tools, channel and people to guide you through whenever you face difficulties or challenges throughout works or personal matter.
cons:
Full of challenging in term of fast pace and dynamic pace at periodic timeframe. Suitable for someone who is looking for
Advice to Management
Salary and benefits for the employees are always the key factor to attract or retain the talented / experienced employees. Perhaps the company could have consistent review and do timely adjustment of pay and benefit for those long service employees so that they can feel that their years of experience and contribution are really appreciated over the years instead of rely on yearly basis increment. 

For example, fresh graduate market salary is increased to average $3.5K at outside life science market however, this salary is almost take 4 to 5 years accumulated from annual increment from those who joined years ago. Without timely review, their base salary gap is getting bigger to outside market over the years and employees will start to think of leaving the company instead of motivating them to have more contribution to the organization.

pros: Pay, benefits, colleagues are nice, remote flexibility is great, lots of different departments to move around, room for advancement.
cons:
There is NO training, the packaging department I worked in was extremely unorganized and mismanaged, you're hired and thrown into the mix without much acclimation and expected to manage very process heavy projects without any guidance or support. Very very high turnover as a result of no training, management appears not to understand this correlation.
People are hired to alleviate the turn over, but are not trained, which creates a bottleneck of untrained people and more work for veteran employees in the long run. Suggestions to fix this are not well received.
Advice to Management
Train people, provide support for new hires and veteran workers alike, organize the department so it is actually functional.

pros: Bonuses are very generous. Pay and benefits on par with most large corporation. Excellent opportunities for remote work for white collar employees. Opportunity to transfer within company to different positions.
cons:
Still a great place to be a white male otherwise TFS still needs lots of work. Claims to be woke and inclusive but divisional managers could care less. As a women I have personally experienced and witnessed towards other women and minorities harassment, micro-aggression, hostile work environment and discrimination from the male dominated management team . Its very much a boys club. Until TFS gets serious about inclusion and diversity among managers, I don't see the issue fixing itself. With that being said, some divisions are better than others so do your homework. When interviewing ask about the management team and get a copy of the org chart; ask about turnover or if the person transferred. High turnover or transfer rate is not good sign. Research on LinkedIn for other that may have had that job at TFS and see how long they've been in the position or reach out and see if they'll answer your questions.
Advice to Management
Seriously consider your conscious and unconscious bias. Until you do, TFS isn't the best work environment. You and the company culture still needs a ton of work in this area. Continuing to shuttle the same white male management team around isn't the answer. You do a survey ever year but never seems to truly address the employee concerns maybe its because divisional and local management doesn't take it seriously and thinks it's joke. Maybe it's time to have employees rate management in the PMD process.

review_title: They are trying to find their way?
pros: There are some great people to work with, and they do give some flexible time-off benefits. Supervisors (in most of the groups) are very understanding and will work with you and as hard as you do.
cons:
Management is severely misplaced, most not having experience in this field but hired due to having a high level degree. A lot of miscommunications occur with having too many cooks. It doesn't help that with higher -up people not understanding the work and processes that occur in a Biotech company, which leads to a lot of unnecessary processes, instruments, and programs being used. I know it is still in start-up but I can see there being problems for a while until they get their bearings straight. Also, they have one recruiter that is notorious (everyone in the branch know and hate him, even supervisors and managers. A lot of them will go behind his back to the recruiting manager to work their own offers for people they want, as they have learned why it is hard to fill open spots) for horrible offers, while lying about compensation during the interview process, and when the offer comes it is way less than hat was agreed upon or the range implied. At the moment there is a departure of about an employee every other week from my branch and never from manufacturing. I have learned that they are, probably, the only group that is fair with compensation and responsibilities.
Advice to Management
Hire people with experience, fancy degrees do not mean anything especially if it is not relevant to the position. Experience brings understanding of the processes, and how to better execute them and manage and give direction to their group.

Great culture.

cons:

Does not offer equal access to remote work opportunities (management is allowed to swap to remote, average workers are not).

review_title: Decent company for retirees and part time students
pros: Decent place as a training company and if you would like to retire. Job can become mundane if you are not willing to learn. Recommend if you want to take on part time studies as there will be a decent work life balance.
cons:
Base pay is low and no career progression. Seen technicians work for 5-6 years before even being considered to be promoted to senior technician. They would rather hire a senior technician than to promote one of their own technician who is fully capable. 

Company also likes to promote that they have a high employment rate but in actual fact, it’s due to turnover rate being really high hence resulting in the need to hire for replacement.
Advice to Management
Respect your employees more and take their feedback into action steps. Many people have left due to the same issue but nothing was done. Focus on talent retention.

pros: Performance oriented but humane leadership that makes smart investments, and fosters a collaborative work climate. Internal talent gets developed by trainings and possibilities of lateral moves. Multiple grass root and public outreach efforts that are supported by leadership. Pretty decent benefits and work life balance. Good work climate, fitness center, good lunch options on site and nearby. Family friendly, open to flexible hours if it does not interfere with performance.
cons:
It’s a big company, which provides stability and options but it also limits operational flexibility by requiring more bureaucracy. No onsite child care options. Compensation may not be above industry average but the pros make up for it in my opinion.
Advice to Management
Upper management stepped up their game in giving back and being more tuned into their workforce. This definitely improved engagement and the feeling of being valued. Recruiting efforts need to be taken up a notch, especially in the current hot market in life tech.

pros: Bonus is 100% or more
cons:
- employees are stretched beyond office hours for trivial issues such as meetings, plannings, open-source projects(excluding 8 hours of deliverables/day)
- resources shared across multiple projects without sync across managers. No priority set for deliverables
- An immediate joinee will be expected to give 30, 60, 90 day presentations where new design changes need to be proposed for product; these presentations will be equivalent to interviews where management will mock your efforts stating you need to scale
-any new technology or technically interesting problem must be taken up on weekends and beyond office hours
- for a new joinee, a 'major secret project' will be assigned which cannot be spoken of and must be done beyond office hours. In case you deny, they will keep requesting you to take it up in 1-to-1 meetings with manager
- toxic work culture as due to above points, everyone is stretched all the time. For a new joinee, no time to understand the product, your buddy will also not have time to help you out as he/she is stretched as well
- lengthy meetings extended for trivial issues. 15-30 mins Scrum goes on from 1-1.5 hours. Other than this, 4-5 hours of meetings every day for developers other than their 8 hours of dev work. You can expect a a 10.30 PM call in the morning followed by a 6 am call in the morning 
- aggresive management where they may insult/scold you in monthly meetups when your demo your leanings
- No process for anything. Right from onboarding, to setup, to access to offboarding, everything was a mess. eg : Getting access to Jira, Confluence took a month. 
**poor work life balance, toxic culture. One may be mentally impacted to work normal hours after being a part of this organization
Advice to Management
- Please respect your employees and have a professional code of conduct
- Treat your employees with respect
- Ensure work life balance by ensuring extended hours are not practiced unless critical(like production issue). Don't ask employees to extend regularly for trivial issues such as meetings, yearly planning
- Don't repeatedly ask your developers to participate in hackathons and open-source projects if they deny it. Delivering project work in time itself is demanding. Please check how other product based orgs are handling their developers
- If you're following agile, have dedicated scrum masters and product owners for all teams. Scrum master must ensure there are no external requests to the scrum team that may affect the deliverables
- Have separate SDETs for automation and product owners/scrum masters as manual testers

pros: Working for TFS at their Vacaville location was the best work experience in my career. The team I worked with were easy to get along with, collaborative, supportive, and had a great sense of humor. Their short and long term disability is also excellent.
cons:
Unfortunately for TFS as a whole as I understand it there is virtually almost no upward mobility and the starting pay at the bottom of the ladder is way below the industry as a whole. If you start as a material handler it's almost impossible to grow beyond that even if you have education or further training.
Advice to Management
This would be advice for TFS senior executives or state directors since managers of sites don't have the power to just raise pay however they want. Pay people a living wage starting at the bottom (i.e. the ability to comfortably afford a place to live within 20mi of the business site, start/support a family, pay living expenses, and take a nice vacation once a year). If your unwilling to do that then at least have ways to recognize talent or those whom are putting in extra effort to succeed to allow them to have more professional upward mobility.

review_title: Great start for career, but move on.
pros: Thermo Fisher Scientific offers rewards and incentives for work, and lots of great people to work with. You'll learn a lot here. Executive leadership took care of employees during the pandemic.
cons:

Many are expected to work and respond to work 24/7. Easy to burn out here.
Advice to Management
Too many inexperienced leaders in charge, and many are promoted too early in their career to be effective. The mistreatment of your skilled individual contributors is why many of them leave.

review_title: 5 years later - a great career choice
pros:
This is a company that has longevity and stability.

The senior leadership will give bonuses to all colleagues when the corporation does really well. From 2020 until now, the company has issued 6 weeks of bonus pay to all everyone but the most senior leaders (who I assume get paid plenty). I'm not expecting that to continue forever, but it's great that they are comfortable sharing part of the wealth.

You can make a career here by applying for different roles both at a local site and across the global Thermo Fisher Community. There is opportunity for upward trajectory.

The Engineering Department is never boring. You learn something new every day. Often the new thing to learn starts with "What is that and what on earth does it do?"
cons:
Like most large corporations, you can feel like a number sometimes.

Pay is fair compared to the overall market. There is an aspect of trading a higher salary for job security.

Communications from the top tends to be geared towards personnel who have ready access to a computer or company issued mobile phone. It can be challenging to get the CEO's guidance to colleagues who do not have these things: like production and warehouse personnel.
Advice to Management
Always continue to innovate communications all the way to front line production colleagues.

Continue to expand market opportunities.

review_title: Great Experience, Poor Work Life Balance
pros:
1.) Business is booming with the pandemic, so there is job security.
2.) Frequent bonuses when the company is doing well.
3.) Learn a lot about how a large company runs and it's different systems/interactions.
cons:
1.) As the title says, there is poor work life balance at Thermo Fisher. Expect to work more than 40 hours and do the jobs of 2-3 people. I frequently saw emails come in past 10 PM and sometimes even 1 AM weekdays and weekends. There's also been meeting invites for a 7:30 AM meeting, sent at 9 PM the previous day.
2.) Thermo underpays compared to industry standard, which contributes to long hiring times to find a replacement when someone leaves. A candidate is found, but then they take a higher paying offer at another company.
3.) Poor communication from management. A lot of times there were changes to the organization structure that were communicated last minute. 
4.) High turnover. There's some departments that have people there 10+ years and some 1-2 years, but nothing in between.
Advice to Management
Start paying competitively and hire more people. Some departments need their workforce doubled. Otherwise, you'll find yourself continuing to struggle to retain talent.

pros: The Company has been largely benefitting from the pandemic, so there is some job security.
cons:
You are expected to work more than 40 hour weeks and lots of times you will be receiving urgent texts or emails on the weekend. Your life revolves around your job, yet to Thermo you are simply an input into their machine. They will churn and squeeze as much as they can out of you for the lowest price possible. Work life balance does not exist and compensation is below market rate.
Advice to Management
If you are going to "emphasize" work/life balance then you should start at the top so that requests aren't trickling down resulting in late nights and weekends. Also, try to pay men and women equally - especially when it comes to bonus percentages, if they have the same experience and are in the same band, they should have the same bonus percentage.

pros: What I love about this company is the people I work with and our common mission to improve patients’ lives. TFS Cambridge has a lot of talented people imbedded in the fabric of the company’s heritage and strengths. Recognition is above average compared to most companies and company is generous with overtime if this is something you’re into. This is a great company to obtain experience in different aspect of the field within a short people of time.
cons:
Remember how I said “overtime” and “obtain experience [...] within a short period of time” earlier? Well, there’s a downside to all that. The reason why you can make a good chunk of money (as an hourly employee) is due to the fact that there’s a huge lack of resources namely workforce. The hiring process takes about 2-3 months to get hired therefore the workload is always challenging since most employees have to wear different hats within their role. And spend long hours inside the lab if no one is available to relieve you.
These are minimal cons but I felt it’s important to let you know what you’re getting into.
The biggest cons of all time? Paid parking ($430/month and they reimburse $270), expensive health insurance and subpar base pay. Although the TFS claims their pay is competitive, they pay employees 15-20% under what other biotech companies pay for the same roles. They used to offer daily passes for people who drive to work and now the only people who get a monthly pass are upper management (day or night) and the staff working at night. If you work during the day and you’re not upper management, you’re doomed. One more thing to add: if you’re trying to be smart and save some money by switching to night which will give you a monthly parking pass in the blue garage, and a night differential of 15% (where most companies offer a 20+% night differential), it will take you months or they will just forget about you because they hire few people at a time and it takes 2-3 months before they operate on their respective 12-hr rotating shift (they will work Monday-Friday 9-5 for an additional 2 weeks before switching).
Advice to Management
Expedite the hiring process. I get that the goal is to hire talented individuals but if the hiring and onboarding process takes 2-3 months total + an additional 2 weeks for basic training, there’s no movement for people to switch to nights. Now, a lot of people want to switch to nights because they are not comfortable overpaying health insurance, parking with a pay lower than most biotech companies. Fix this...

review_title: Great place to learn new skills but managers or not responsible and unorganized
pros: As a scientist you learn all sorts of techniques you can apply to your resume and there is a lot of knowledge in that site.
cons:
Co-workers. Some co-workers were ancient and refused to change there ways with new guidelines and the managers were not confident enough to correct them. Speaking of managers, none of them were responsible, they would kick the can of responsibility down the chain and step on anyone to climb the corporate ladder. For a multi-billion dollar company they couldn't even purchase new equipment, we use ancient instruments to QC finished goods for customers using way more advanced machinery. I once asked if a piece of equipment that was broken could still be used for sterile techniques and the response was "we don't have anther quality inspection for 10 months so we can use it for that long". I loved doing the work it was just the people were the problems.
Advice to Management
Get more responsible people as managers, stop blaming other departments when things don't go as planned. Target the problem not the people. Your work instructions are all terrible, some are wrong and no one bothers to update them because they don't have the time so you should make time for that, the goal of the work instruction is to have someone new to the team be able to complete the procedure without crossing out items and adding new items in. Get a better inventory system and have planning communicate their needs better to the other departments.

pros:
Laid back
No progression
Work life balance
cons:
No progression
Really low wage but supplement OT to sometimes make up the market rate
Does not focus on removing the problematic people
Boss lashes at you in group chat if he is not happy just to shame you
If you hold a senior role, tardiness goes unpunished, making work related mistakes is overlooked.
Speaking out means a cry for help rather than simply trying to improve the situation.
The seniors have trivial rivalry amongst themselves which makes day to day silly.
Advice to Management
Hire the right people with the right salary to make them do the job right. 
Send them for team bonding to foster better work relations within shift teams.
Send the people for external courses to improve their personal development, it is not always about what the company makes but also how the company help the people develop.
Finally, recognise red flags when your people give feedback in the annual management survey.

Management is generally incompetent, told to "just make it work" and "this is just the way it is" while process improvement worry only about their own metrics to increase their bonuses. People are treated as robots by management. Hopefully unique to this site, but haven't worked at any other sites.
Advice to Management
Treat people like human beings. Do not "volunteer" people for weekend work. Attempt to reduce the turnover rate as opposed to "make it work."

pros: Interesting tools available to learn such as power BI and redshift. However each business unit uses them differently
cons:
Where to begin.. sink or swim culture.
No training or proper explanations for what expectations are. Constant use of financial or product that are not explained or misunderstood by most. 

You need to sound smart but not actually be smart because they care about the story more than the data. Any mistakes in incorrect data can be blamed on you.

There are at least 7 different erps.

You may work late and still be expected to attend meetings at 7am!
Advice to Management
Give proper training and guidance to new employees when they onboard. Dissolve the sink or swim culture and actually get people aligned on goals objectives and strategy.

Repor

pros: Steady work and lots of overtime for hourly employees.
cons:
Huge disconnect between lower levels where things happen to upper management. Management does not want to hear any bad news, just meet your numbers, so issues have escalated and magnified without a real effort to correct them.

We are a "lean" company, meaning everyone is overwhelmed. Couple this with a severe talent drain where most competent people leave in 6 -18 months you get a rapidly deteriorating condition. Most of the people who stay either are too lazy to look for another job or would not hack it elsewhere.

The personnel situation is so bad we can't get people for the production floor because the wages are too low compared to other jobs in the area, and management is spread so thin there is only one supervisor for four departments. There has been no department manager for a year. Plus most other companies do not work with dangerous chemicals.

Coming in I was told there were plenty of opportunities for advancement but reality is I am against a glass ceiling. Most positions from department manager on up are sourced outside. 

Procedures and work instructions are inaccurate or nonexistent in some departments.

Competent people are quickly overwhelmed by work and unsolvable issues then leave.
Substantial amounts of money are spent on 3rd party warehouses because the facility was not designed to handle the volume demanded from it. Production is in the same situation.

Continuity of management:
Eight facility managers in ten years.
Ten HR managers in eight years. HR is worthless anyway.
Four division leaders in five years.
Advice to Management
Get involved with your company and the people who work for you, particularly at the levels where money is made. And don't be afraid of making a real decision instead of leaving problems for your replacement in a year and a half. Who leaves it for their replacement, etc.

review_title: A well-managed company that cares about it's employees
pros: It is very clear that Thermo Fisher Scientific values their employees. They take the yearly survey feedback seriously and are continually striving to make the company better for their customers and employees. The pay is good, the PTO is great and the COVID bonuses provided to all employees were more than generous. They set realistic budgets and goals that are attainable unlike previous companies I've worked for where they set your goal incredibly high to avoid having to pay bonuses/commissions. I am never worried about job stability and have coworkers and managers that I can trust and rely on. There is also a lot of opportunity to move around the company if you want.
cons:
The company can be difficult to navigate due to its size. The health insurance plan is okay, although a bit expensive. This is offset by a generous contribution from the company into our HSA/HRA.
Advice to Management
I am so impressed by your decisions and management during the COVID pandemic. I saw many companies lay off their workforce or make deep cuts which drastically hurt many of my friends and family. You made strategic decisions to protect us during the uncertainty and then rewarded us when the pandemic boosted our numbers. That kind of investment in your employees speaks volumes and is why I give everything I have every day. I am proud to work for Thermo Fisher Scientific.
8 people found this review helpful

review_title: Growing Fast, comes with growing pains
pros: The company is growing quickly and has frequently given cash bonuses throughout the year depending on how the company is performing.
cons:
Due to the rapid growth you feel the growing pains. It is very common to feel overworked/understaffed. Frequent organizational changes can be detrimental to progress. I had 3 different managers in a 1.5 year period (my job/responsibilities did not change) all due to organizational restructuring. This can make it difficult to get support and coaching from your manager(s).

Annual raises are poor. For consistent performers and very positive annual reviews you can expect a raise between 0.5% and 3%. I give their compensation adjustment system and its implementation a D + grade.
Advice to Management
Be more transparent about the metrics that are used for compensation decisions. In my experience they have been pretty arbitrary and rarely outpace normal inflation. This company is extremely profitable and all of its prices are adjusted with inflation annually. So annual compensation increases should at least match inflation. It is easy to improve profitability metrics when you increase prices based on inflation without also adjusting your employees compensation.

pros:
Large company that's constantly growing through mergers and acquisitions means the corporation is very stable, your job is pretty safe.
More established divisions that have been under the Thermo umbrella for a longer time are more stable and the systems are more mature. Recently acquired or growing businesses will be rough around the edges.
You can gain experience with this company. There are growth opportunities for early career professionals.
cons:
Compensation isn't competitive, you may start at an alright salary but target raises of 2% every year means you will fall behind quickly. If a manager has more than one good employer,annual raises become a very difficult subject with such a small pool to allovate. HR waits for employees to threaten to leave before considering adjusting salaries to market rates. This practice creates a culture where high performers are almost always considering leaving the company. You will have to be at least a director to receive stock as a compensation vehicle. Upper management turnover is low. Frontline and middle management turnover is high. 
Corporate benefits are about average, discretionary spending is on the stingier side (even directors don't get business class airfare for business travel).
The company has very little "culture", likely due to the corporate acquisition activity over the past 15 years. Thermo is generally more interested in growth than doing well in areas they already have business.
Thermo will outsource as much as possible, you will likely have to call a 1-800 for any kind of HR or IT support and wait several days for a response.
Later career professionals have limited growth potential, although there is an individual contributor career ladder, anything above Sr. Scientist is extremely rare so you will find people that are at the top of their pay band sooner or later.
Advice to Management
Slow down on the stock buybacks and reconsider compensation planning strategy. HR is a very top heavy part of the business with seemingly no accountability for employee satisfaction (upon reading this they would probably interview managers to see what they did wrong, act like there was an action plan in place and then hire another VP of HR and do nothing).

review_title: Finance talented, but very hard workplace to navigate
pros: Great if you're young and have energy to put in hours of work. Easy to move at analyst levels among large sites, but very difficult to move around in some of the smaller sites as most areas require you to be in the office. The exception is the FLDP programs where they are supported financially with moving locations. The knowledge of finance at the Director level is great and they are willing to train their top performers. There are some really great people to work for in this organization. Networking and mentoring although highly encouraged for job growth can still be awkward at times. Finding personal advocates is even more difficult for advancing careers.
cons:
Up or out culture for management or leadership with pre-planned strategies already set for rotating employees. Really bad HR issues in Pittsburgh that are ignored or not supported including harassments, diversity & inclusion, supporting family or health situations. However, I believe HR is attempting to improve. Constant position banding changes that have not been a positive experience for many of the personnel. Finance specifically encourages people to rotate every two years, there is no stability in positions. Reorganizations and responsibilities change constantly occur to a point where performance reviews are impacted. The Pittsburgh finance teams have tighter budgets that usually do not allow for frequent resource increases nor for travel with business partners.
Advice to Management
You lose top performers constantly to some of the items pointed out in the Cons section. One negative comment or situation can ruin someone's reputation. Provide people the benefit of the doubt by looking for a single instance vs repetitive behaviors especially when requesting employees to work more than 50 hrs per week in a high stress environment. Learn to coach them to a better place and you will be able to retain better talent as well as have a much healthier workplace. Support those individuals going through life changes as they'll be more dedicated and loyal. Please also work on a zero tolerance or even a strikes policy for all complaints in some of your more serious HR related issues regardless of rank or work responsibilities. Your people need to be more supported.

review_title: Thermo Fisher's Covid-19 response was shameful.
pros: Benefits and some good co-workers.
cons:
o Their only action during the first month of the pandemic was to provide every employee with a letter from management designating them as essential personnel and eliminating any acceptable excuse for them to miss work.
o No masks were provided to any employees until weeks after the first positive case in the facility. When management announced the first positive case in the facility, it was done in an area of the warehouse where social distancing was impossible. Until that point morning stretches had been held in the same area. 
o Management informed employees at a facility-wide meeting that hand sanitizer would not prevent the spread of the virus (the accuracy of which is up for debate), in their mind presumably excusing the fact that there was almost none available in the entire facility (until several weeks after numerous positive cases in the facility).
o Despite emails sent by management assuring that cleaning supplies would be readily available to every employee, none were made available. I was at no time made aware of the location of, or witnessed anyone using, cleaning supplies to wipe down equipment that was used by multiple employees in numerous departments every day. 
o Despite emails sent by management assuring employees that all workspaces in the facility would be cleaned on a daily basis, entire areas were not cleaned for weeks, if at all. 
o Employees were still expected to work in crowded conditions for 50-60 hour (mandatory) weeks after positive cases began accumulating in the facility. 
o Employees who were responsible and (despite no encouragement from management) were tested for COVID-19 (and tested positive) were granted short term disability at a reduced rate from their normal salary. Those who exhibited symptoms but were never tested were compensated for their time missed with a normal 40 hours. 
o Employees returning from time missed due to COVID-19 were not approached by management to welcome them back and ask how they were feeling; it was just another day.
o When the pandemic was in full force management began lecturing employees to practice social distancing (despite the fact it was physically impossible if the goal was to actually complete your work), while not utilizing it themselves.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Pay is pretty good if searching for a great entry level paying job. The work is not physical as much as it is more about using your mind and hands. Raises according to your performance. Company hands you a check for a turkey every November. A lot of elderly female and male employees.
cons:
It may be, in a lot of ways, a safe place to work. But, they still have a long way to go to completely protect their employees from unknowingly getting sick from exposure to the clinical trial drugs that people expose themselves to. Favoritism is a thing here from supervisors down as far as I could tell, if they don’t like you, primary workers will run you out, or shut you out. They like to periodically edit your job title duties by adding responsibility, with or without your consent. And not to mention will not compensate you for those added responsibilities. Supervision can be very gun-ho yet that goes for a-lot of people here. And I speak especially of those who work in Primary. Cut pay instead of raise it when COVIID hit this only effected Supervision and up.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees when they raise concerns. Provide better and longer coaching to Room Leaders and Tech IIIs. Quit adding responsibilities to your people without offering a a form of compensation. Aside from the compensation that they have already earned.

review_title: Big Public Company - Where Will They Go Next
pros: Large company with excellent benefits. Direct manager was fantastic and provided opportunities for growth and training, although difficult to move up or around unless you are able to relocate. Lots of tools at your disposal, however, the layers within Marketing can slow things down. Company heavily weighted in the Life Science arena and interested to see where they will go next with all the recent acquisitions.
cons:
They are not shy about telling you that your job is only there from quarter to quarter if you make your numbers. Miss two quarters in a row as a business unit and employees are easily dismissed with "restructures", regardless of tenure. While benefits are second to none, compensation is not in line with market and annual merit increases are minimal at best. Make sure to negotiate strong when you start, for not only compensation but vacation time and banding.
Advice to Management
Your people are your best assets. Treat your employees at least as well as you would your shareholders.

pros: easy to hire. friendly working environment
cons:
overloaded schedule and tasks. company seems to take care of employees, but in the long term they actually dont. continuously saying "yes" to customers even if there is no capacity for the workers. and the whole load falls on the workers shoulders. quite unorganized. no project management systems to help managers do their job. too many side-systems and you are losing track.
Advice to Management
Say "yes" to new Quality hires. Say "no" to the client sometimes. build a stable environment for the employees. invest in a collective project management system asap. But most of all, screen your current higher management employees, band 7-10, because they do a lousy job on supporting and recognizing the lower band workers. Also, focus on promoting based on skills and value in the company. not on the time the employee has remained in a position.

pros: As a CMO in gene therapy, there are endless opportunities to learn here. People are excited to do the right thing and contribute. Lots of energy, focused on doing the best they can. Small site allows for plenty of collaboration with other departments, and people are very friendly and willing to share information to help others. Always plenty to do and learn, and to get promoted/switch departments faster than at a larger company.
cons:
Lack of experienced management as far as timelines, communicating between departments, and actively listening to/acting on feedback. Almost no recognition of hard work, overall site-wide. Not enough personnel for amount of work; most people do the work of 2-3 people. General feeling of constantly putting out fires that could lead to frustration and burnout.
Advice to Management
Be more mindful of your blind spots; look for qualified and experienced people to fill in the gaps and LISTEN to them rather than settling for who is most readily available. And take a long hard look at your lack of diversity in management. Representation matters.

review_title: Great mission, wonderful people, slow growth
pros:
- wonderful mission serving science 
- smart, ambitious, positive outlook colleagues
- overall good work addressing current climate and environment and doing its part to support and make impact
- CEO is caring and very smart, very much approve of how he handled 2020
- Company was honest and transparent during the chaos of 2020, and when the company did well, it was shared back with employees - restoring the comp that was reduced to get through spring and summer
- direct line to knowing the value of work every day - serving science to make the world healthier, cleaner and safer is in everything the company does
cons:
- super super HUGE corporation that makes decision making slow
- unclear upward growth opportunities even though career development is a hot topic
- murky pay transparency 
- D&I in senior director and higher levels especially in IT
- slow to fund progress in digital orgs, but are quick to fund in other areas & outsourcing
- upward mobility is dependent on managers knowing you and your work (lends well to extraverts, not so much introverts)
Advice to Management
- improve diverse hiring pipelines
- work towards pay parity, and be transparent about pay bands and compensation
- continue to drive towards mission driven work in more ways as a company, not just enabling other companies to do so

pros: The compensation for the job is very good considering the tasks performed. Expectations are clear, it's very much a 'learn as you go' type job.
cons:
The work can be very repetitive for hours on end and can get tedious. Not much opportunity for advancement.
Advice to Management
The current introduction manual is not useful at all, in my time there I didn't use anything from it. I had to learn everything from other employees who took the time to show me things instead, a lot of procedures were not explained. Rather than explaining cleaning, I think a manual about packaging direction would be more useful. For instance, talking about how stickers must be placed specifically according to instructions provided and how checks must be performed by QA's after a round of preparation. These are all things older members taught me, without them I would have not understood anything.

pros: The pay is alright and comes with a decent bonus each year. I was also lucky enough to do quite a lot of travel around Europe helping the events team, and there was a lot of encouragement to develop and grow within the team, unfortunately it was only to management which is something I wasn't keen on. The people there are great to work and socialise with and a there is a relaxed atmosphere in general.
cons:
The business is full of snakes, nobody wants to make a decision and things take forever to get completed. There is a lot of sucking up and the people on the ground don't have a voice and have to follow the leaders unconditionally. Until you sell your soul and make it into senior level you're just another number, and there are very few people that get into the senior positions that do it off their own merit or experience, it's more about who you know and what impression you've made on the big wigs.
Advice to Management
Just because someone is in a senior position, it doesn't mean they know what is best, and a lot of the time they don't know what they are talking about. Listen to the people doing the leg work as they know first hand what does and doesn't work from their own experience.

pros: Starting pay for fresh grad ok, people lower than senior management level are nice to work with, potential high exposure to multiple ERP systems, benefits ok, product created helps mankind, potential exposure to tasks beyond your department, challenging and fast paced environment, exposure to international people as it is an MNC.
cons:
Senior management don't seem to care that at least 1 finance employee has left the organization since December 2019. Even HR does not seem to care despite this issue being brought up to them. Don't appreciate current staff but when they leave, usually they are replaced with higher level personnel, or suddenly we cannot hire a replacement headcount and the overworked team needs to cover for said person who left. Keep looking to cut headcount without understanding the nature of the work people are doing. Only hear what they want to hear and don't accept the truth if it is not aligned with what they want (e.g. teams are not working enough hours despite the team clearly working over time even before COVID. Extremely political and toxic environment to work in. Difficult career mobility upwards because senior management only like managerial level people instead of people who can do the day-to-day work, and their high and unobtainable expectations of lower level staff just to move up 1 measly level. Stress can be so bad that employee health is jeopardized.
Advice to Management
To the corporate team - take a hard look at what is going on. Don't rely on the local management team to fix this, the team has lost trust in them. Just ask any of the other international teams who have had to deal with the Singapore team how difficult it has been trying to work with the team now. 

To the local management team - If you keep this up and don't care about the team and their wellbeing and refuse to listen to what you do not want to hear, you will continue to see more people leave. You can attempt to foster "kinship" by making the teams return to the office. You may try to act nice to those who remain. But there is no point conducting interviews when you've lost the trust of the people, and everyone can smell from a mile away that you're just being nice so that you may find out who is the next person to quit. It does not work to promise a promotion and salary increase only when a person has tendered their resignation. 

Stop being a yes-man to all requests thrown from upper management at the detriment of those who have to do the work.
19 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Thermo Fisher Scientific invests heavily in it's leaders and is always looking to accelerate talent into and around the organization. From the top (Marc C.) down there is a consistent message to be the best provider for our customers and if our product or services are not the best or most desired option, then we need to do better to make it the best.
cons:
It's a fast-paced environment and you have to be ready to embrace change and growth. This may not be the ideal combination for all, but it can be very exciting and rewarding for those that want to take on the challenge
Advice to Management
Continue to support all employees and be cognizant of work/life balance as the company rapidly expands to meet growth demands. Ensuring a healthy and diverse company culture (where high turnover is avoided) is just as vital for long term success and meeting financial and PPI KPIs efficiently by retaining talent and not having to continually re-hire and re-train people.

review_title: Conscientious leadership, benefits middle of the road
cons:
ientious leadership, benefits middle of the road
2 Nov 2020 - Marketing 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Conscientious leadership, excellent corporate resources for employees, highly collaborative environment, internal job-seeking encouraged, Health benefits extraordinary for some chronic diseases. Lives its mission to make the world cleaner, healthier, and safer. CEO leads the company in a unique way, where everyone bands together in times of economic turmoil to avoid job loss and if you hang in you are rewarded in the long-run.
Cons
Generally, benefits are middle of the road in every aspect. The constant movement of/within departments means there is always at least 1 man down on a team, often more. Promotions are rare, interviewing for another role is the best way to get ahead, but it can be very competitive. Information flows top-down so having a good manager who is transparent is critical to your success.
Advice to Management
Make 360 reviews mandatory for all managers every year, or every other year, so that ineffective and toxic leadership can be identified.

review_title: Proactive Professional Top Down Discussions of Race In America Welcome
pros:
Riots surrounding George Floyd this summer prompted a management response that has revolutionized Thermo Fisher's external commitment to ending discrimination. Management has stepped up its game in ways that are not placation. There has been a truly pivotal and dynamic shift in the inclusiveness and welcoming nature of discussion and understanding within company social media. 

It has led me to being proud to work for this company after multiple years of thinking that they were "just another big company that doesn't care". 

IT department has a core structure of dedicated, qualified individuals working together to support common goals.

Annual employee feedback survey is actually taken to heart by management and I have seen improvement based on feedback year over year.

Job Stability During COVID. My team is global, so I already worked remotely.
cons:
Promotions difficult depending on department. Lots of opportunities to move internally does generally move problem co-workers out of their current position. If you like your department, your boss will have to fight to get you promoted.

Like any job, your boss will determine if you like your position or not. This is the first year that I've had the same boss from goal setting to goal review (1 year), making it insanely hard to get promoted.

Unclear why some executives are on a fast track when they don't understand their divisions well.
Advice to Management
Continue to be proactive in bias training & commitments to diversity hires. 

Do more to recognize & review employees who have been here for 3+ years to see if their managers who keep moving are stopping them from getting promoted. 

Have a larger commitment to controlled documentation training, especially to preserve tribal knowledge. 

Employ more women in higher management positions/senior staff.
1 person found this review helpful

pros: Good pay and decent benefits
cons:
There is more of an emphasis on maintaining the status quo than on innovation (which is supposedly one of their core "values" but it is never practiced). The Practical Process Improvement (PPI) initiative is based on decades-old Total Quality Management (TQM) concepts and I did everything I could to upgrade the company to Lean. However, I was fought at every turn for telling the truth about PPI's limitations and trying to make real improvements.
Advice to Management
Immediately scrap PPI and implement Lean using outside experts (no one I met there besides me had any real understanding of Lean or even basic tenets of process improvement). Redo your metrics to support the Lean effort (the experts will tell you what they are). 
Fix your Ethics program to actually work - which means don't use your own HR department to investigate/determine ethics violations because they will never find any as their job focus is to protect senior management from workers/whistleblowers who report ethical lapses by them. These are the two main reasons why I left and I know many others who left because of the toxic work environment. 
Also, you need to be more concerned about putting people in leadership positions that actually have the talent and ability to do the job than just trying to improve diversity to win awards. Applaud the push to improve diversity but the people need to also know how to do the jobs for which they are hired. Last two directors were complete disasters with no leadership skills or relevant knowledge/background in the field of process improvement.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Colleagues were the only good thing.
cons:
- Not every manager is a leader.
- the company’s motto “helping customer to enable to make the world healthier, cleaner and safer” does not apply to ANZ business. Only few people take this vision statement to heart and all others are after sales funnel and targets.
If targets are not met, managers put you on PIP without giving warning.
- every individual learn at different pace, especially for someone who just started the role/ new to the industry. This is not a company for a graduate because they do not have effective training programs that cater to graduates and people who are new to the industry.
- if you are looking to work in a pressure built environment , this is the perfect job but if you are looking to grow into the role please do not apply to this company. They will look at the numbers. Employees are just numbers.
- the human resource is also very biased; they only listen to the management. So do not waste time talking to anyone, they don’t listen instead they blame you for complaining. 
- They do not train you on the analytics programs and database; they expect you to learn it on your own on your time. 
- The company makes you feel alone and gossips make it very toxic environment to work.
- they presume that the pay they give you compensates for the pressures but NO it does not.

In short don’t work for this company. It’s just a pressure cooker where managers use micro managing, intimidation to get the work done.
Advice to Management
Not every manager is a leader. Human Resources should not be biased and should listen to anyone without judgement.

review_title: One of the worst companies to work for - bar none
pros: Generous expense account with little to no brow-beating for usage (within reason, of course). I presume that they think that if they have you traveling 100% of the time, then maybe they think that at least they can be a little generous with expenses?
cons:
100% ridiculous amount of travel. They preach work-life balance but have no problem having you travel 7 days a week. Your time/life is at their disposal.
Advice to Management
Practice what you preach; say as you do, then do as you say. Management would say that they'd never put you in certain situations, but then turn right around and assign you to those tasks they said they'd never put you in - and then reprimand you for trying your best (but invariably coming up short). They would instruct you to always keep them informed; however when matters would arise that require immediate attention/decision (as they always do in field service), management would get around to replying to you 3-4 days later when you originally needed a decision in 3-4 minutes. Thermo epitomizes the adage that they set you up to fail time and time again. I left Thermo before having secured another job because I was so miserable - as is this company.

review_title: Stable, solid somewhat boring company that can't compete in CA market
pros: Mission and vision of company are great. The stock performs well. Most of the leaders are principled and experienced--not a lot of jerks around. Very innovative when it comes to the products they make at many of the sites.
cons:
No clue on how to be competitive in Silicon Valley--no new hire grants, limited refresh grants, low salaries. The upper management believes that since turnover is so low, nothing needs to change but they are missing the change to attract and retain the brightest. Many people leave due to the stagnation. Also VERY matrixed, very bureaucratric and not very innovative when it comes to processes. Also every single dollar is scrutinized--many layers of approval needed for almost everything.
Advice to Management
Lighten up. You've got great people working for you--if you just let them do their jobs and remove barriers. The technology is cutting edge--let the employees be creative and innovative and get rid of stifling bureaucracy.

location: Warrington, North West England, England, England
review_title: Engaging role with great progression opportunities.
pros:
- There's a strong focus on personal development if you're looking to progress, with career meetings/advice, development plans with your team leader/supervisor, etc.

- Career progression is certainly encouraged, with a wide range of roles to move into.

- A strong focus on the health and safety of everyone on site.

- Our pay is reasonable, comparable roles at a lot of competitors are a 1-4 grand less.

- Plenty of training to finish, there are always new things to do and learn if you start to get bored with your current work.

- Our days are consistently busy, you aren't drowning in work but you have more than enough to keep you engaged, the majority of my days fly by. No need for clock watching!
cons:
Some of the work is easy but long-winded. If you're looking for more mentally engaging/complex work that will require troubleshooting then you'll need to have 1-2 years experience under your belt before you can progress into those types of roles.
Advice to Management
Definitely doing a good job, they keep the site and workers in mind. Always looking at ways to increase our site profitability and this in-turn offers very good job security/stability.

review_title: Growing Company, Poorly Integrated, Dysfunctional, Slow at Execution
pros:
- Fantastic 401K match and the vesting period is short compared with competitors
- Great resources (ability to get lab supplies at or near cost)
- Company hosts many exciting events and workshops throughout the year and are great opportunities to gain skills or volunteer
- Company is very lean, and is heavily focused on data metrics and KPIs, I really appreciated the focus on continuous improvement
- The education scholarship is generous, albeit more restrictive compared with other employers
- Healthcare offerings are variable depending on the group and region, some pre-merger legacy plans that Thermo has retained are truly unmatched
- Company has a relatively young, vibrant workforce and is growing
- On-site amenities, including gym and cafeteria (where available) are cheap and accessible
- WFH flexibility is great if you get the right manager and department
cons:
- PTO policy, though on the surface fairly generous at 3 weeks starting, is inflexible and difficult to navigate in my experience compared with competitors (example: maternity leave)
- The company is an agglomeration of a number of smaller companies that were the product of Thermo's buying binge over the past couple of years. There remains quite a bit of overlap and silos that result in unnecessary duplication of functions and resources, territory disputes, office politics, and communication challenges. Except for a very few functions, expect to be frustrated by this on a regular basis.
- Advancement opportunities are lacking and raises are paltry compared with competitors. The company does emphasize "lateral moves" into other roles, which I appreciatively took advantage of during my career at Thermo Fisher. However, in my own experience many times this resulted in others coming in who were completely unfamiliar with a product line that took on a management or oversight role where they have no clear idea what the product really is, how it is used, or how it is manufactured. It is also exhausting to have to re-introduce yourself to your new manager and to justify your existence and importance to the team if you're doing it 3-4 times a year.
- The websites are truly an absolute dumpster fire and the company has no easy solutions to address it. It is difficult to get a customer interested in a product when they themselves cannot find it on the website.
- Constant instability, turnover, layoffs that weren’t fully thought through, and unrealistic expectations. As a result, there was frequently a lot of friction and resulting drama between on-site employees or underhanded tactics from mid-level managers that subsequently amplified the drama and hampered productivity (i.e. artificially inflating numbers, stealing resources and materials from other groups in the middle of the night to "hold down the budget").
- The open-plan office space and dearth of conference and huddle rooms at many larger sites make it logistically difficult to schedule and hold meetings
- Many of the Senior Directors and VP's seem to have an almost "Cult of Personality" problem. While Thermo Fisher has a top-notch Internal Communications and PR Shop, the focus on AV, bright lights, and showmanship versus more open, honest dialogue and communication results in it being an uninformative pablum. Why does there need to be a DJ and produced light show at a site's quarterly Town Hall discussing company performance? Isn't that a bit excessive? Why does the Leadership and Marketing Teams need to frequently come in and disrupt the lab operation to "play act" science for the camera? If you have a question or concern regarding a decision being rolled out from the top, do not expect a speedy or satisfying answer, or even a forum to gain further clarity
- I did experience the ultimate insult of finding out I was about to be laid off but before that was going to happen, I was asked to train my replacement on another continent.
Advice to Management
It is imperative that Thermo Fisher starts adhering to and complying with labor laws regarding safety and rest breaks for hourly workers, something they are (still) continuing to struggle with at some of the California and Oregon sites. The lack of competence, training, and compliance for some managers and supervisors overseeing hourly employees is, at best, inconsistent across groups, and at worst, negligent. This behavior is unacceptable, it is not building trust with the hourly workforce, and is bound to lead to additional legal action (yes, they have a history). Better HR and EHS infrastructure is needed.

Please do a better job of removing barriers to execution that are slowing down innovation and quality! TFS customers are doing incredibly important work and need those products, if there are issues affecting the quality, efficacy, or integrity of products, these must be addressed by management in a rapid, comprehensive, and meaningful way. Slow-walking or being opaque about an issue because a process must be followed or a sales goal needs to be hit are not acceptable and damages the company's reputation.

review_title: Employees are just resources, not people. Big-company mgmt mentality.
pros: Stable company, cafe in Pittsburgh HQ
cons:
Management tends to treat employees as nothing more than skill sets, instead of valuing each person for their domain knowledge. There is no company loyalty to the employee, despite employee loyalty and longevity. Internal reorganizations left people in positions where they were not optimally placed, nor happy with the new (forced) position duties. They will not hesitate to then ding them for slower performance and kick them out the door, regardless of how successful they were in previous positions or projects. It felt like the old "underhanded layoff" technique that is common in corporate America.
Advice to Management
Return to a mindset where people are seen as humans first, skill sets second. Reward their loyalty with loyalty to them. Ensure each middle-manager holds these values first and foremost, instead of letting them ruin people's retirements and career growth with their ill-informed decisions to terminate otherwise valuable employees simply because their current project isn't a good fit for them, especially if it was forced upon them. It's understandable that contractors may be let go when projects are completed, but this approach should never apply to permanent folk, and yet I witnessed it first-hand on numerous occasions.

review_title: The good the bad and the ugly
pros:
The Good.
Salary is above average for most fields.
Vast benefit options. Great options such as legal representation and supplement insurance kinda like aphlac.
Yearly bonus up to 16% for non executive bands.
cons:
The Bad.
Only time off is PTO. The vacation, sick,or personal time is all lumped together putting them way behind on work life balance trend.
Annual wage increases usually less than 2% while benefit cost climbs about 2% a year. 

The Ugly.
Covid-19 company response. Showing their true colors.
The company canceled merit increases, reduced salary by up to 25%. The company is also not participating in any government cost share programs to make employees whole. 

This is all happening while the company is growing and profiting from covid-19. Stock is higher than ever. Quarterly earnings showed growth and projections are looking up.
Advice to Management
Profit isn't everything. Post covid-19 world talented workers will be moving towards companies that looked out for employees not profit.

review_title: Be Wary of Promises Made During the Interview and Hiring Processes
pros: Their electron and ion beam technology is top notch.
cons:
Heavy handed management. Managers who do not realize that their people make or break them and so, they should at least do a good job of pretending to care and to support their employees. Expected to complete paperwork and admin tasks on your own time. Too big and bureaucratic.
Advice to Management
During the interview process, when asked about policies such as overtime and company car, do be mealy-mouthed. Do not so overburden managers that they cannot focus on taking care of their reports. Yes, I understand it's a for profit business. When communicating unpleasant news, the manager should own it and not blame superiors or use statements like "upper management is watching." Do not make statements like: "well, that's how we always had to do it when I was an FSE."

pros: Big company, I got to know lots of talented friends, but unfortunately they either got demoted or pushed away
cons:
1) Pay is low compared to its competitors, especially when you divide the pay by the long work hours. 
2) Toxic work environment. No respect for talents. This company is an incubator for work bullies. The real talents either got demoted, or pushed away, because they don't fit in the company vibe. Therefore, if you are a kind person -- be careful, this is not a company for you. 
3) Extremely long work hours. The management expects you to stand-by all the time. One mid-night call and you need to get up and work. No subsidy for overtime work. 
4) Mediocre middle management. Always say Yes to their bosses, very often over promise on deadlines, no matter how ridiculous the request is. Push the employees to work on nights and weekends to make the overpromised deadlines.
Advice to Management
Respect talents. Appreciate their work. Introduce work-life balance.

review_title: Great to grow your skills and make connections
pros: Great opportunity to learn many things from extremely knowledgeable people. Friendly and hard working employees to work with who will always cover your back. Most have flexible schedules and the company retains a cozy atmosphere. Stable work, head count is hard to secure so supervisors would rather help you grow than let you go.
cons:
Toxic "workaholic" culture quietly encourages workers to donate labor to the company by working weekends or 10-12 hour days. Competitors pay significantly more. Poor to nonexistent career advancement; most who I have worked with didn't feel promotions were worth it. Teams are downsized through attrition but expected to maintain output capacity.
Advice to Management
Please invest in your employees, including financially. Stop treating employee salaries and downsizing teams as a profit center. I love the work done here, but competitors paying 25-40% more is very hard to ignore.
