pros: Company offers a pretty good 401k plan with 6% match, WFH opportunity depending on manger, 15 days PTO (no sick time though), 3 floating holidays, 5% discount ESPP, very good tuition reimbursement, 4%-8% performance bonus (recently added) and pretty good benefits offered through Cigna. This is a great company that has had some great growth from an investment standpoint in recent years and is expected to continue growth in the long term plan. Not many days that you are expected to work over 8 hours, but occasionally this does happen.
cons:
The organization is very stingy with raises from what I have experienced. Been at the organization some time now and haven't gotten a raise since I started. Definitely something to consider when negotiating salary in the hiring process. The company also has very convoluted data that is very difficult to work with, not much standardization in regards to how to handle the data to ensure accuracy of reporting. A lot of communication is done through conference calls and there are a lot of fire drills that need to be handled on a day to day basis (this is common anywhere when working with sales people). Management needs to understand the jobs that the employees are faced with better and work on developing employees on a higher level training. Onboarding seems to be low level and doesn't really help since most issues are relatively complex. Sales Directors pretty much run the show at this company and at times ask for some really complex reports that could be simplified or standardized if the company would upgrade some of their internal business systems. Seems like there are a lot of job postings but not much internal movement. Company likes to bring in a lot of people from outside and keep people in their current roles.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the performance review process or make some changes to align with the organization to maintain costs. Stop digging for ways to not give current employees annual raises when the jobs being asked of these employees are not structured very well from an employee onboarding/training process. There is a lot of turnover at the organization due to the lack of culture and difficulty to manage data. Reward your employees for hard work and you might see people stay around longer. Also, invest some money in better systems to get away from so much ad-hoc analysis. Obviously in a senior position there will always be ad-hoc but from my experience 75% of the job is done from scratch and if methodology does not align with what the sales team is looking for it creates a ton of re-work.

review_title: Good company culture for safety and quality
pros: Company does well with communication. There are good corporate culture to drive safety and quality. Process improvements are much encouraged through PPI culture.
cons:
Career development doesn't exist. I am with the company for more than seven years. In those seven years, I have seen mid level management positions vacated 9 times, and 8 of them were filled with external candidates. This is only in one department. That is 11% chance for a mid level manager to be filled by an internal candidate in seven years. This is very good for outside candidates, terrible for company employees. Company is busy educating outside hires and ended up losing be them eventually as well.
Advice to Management
Develop your high potential employees. Employees should be given high priority for career advancement instead of hiring from outside. The loss of knowledge and technical know-how is real and not sustainable. Frequent hiring from outside candidates are demoralizing. That means someone like me will have to rebuild my reputation over and over again to prove myself to the new management. Now I am at the point that I am starting to ask myself why. Why should I even try to be a high performer, given that my career path is leading toward a dead end.

pros: If you stay long enough, you are able to apply internally and move around to different roles since the company is large. The team you work with are usually hard workers.
cons:
Politics, average pay, long hours and cold environment where people are treated like numbers. They think constantly moving around and changing things up (even when it’s not progress) is a good thing which often creates extra unnecessary work. They seem to have a retention issue. I think it’s because there’s really not much they offer that is above the market to motivate employees. There are people who are overpaid and barely do anything and the work gets shoved to a few. There’s not even the cool factor, fun environment or perks to alleviate some of the stress associated with long hours and often unrealistic deadlines. A company like this shouldn’t act top notch if what they offer is average at best. Talent is retained through more than just a steady income. Employees need to feel proud of the company they work for, feel valued, and actually enjoy the environment.
Advice to Management
Kick the lazy unproductive workers out, reward the hard workers. Stop the politics and reorient the focus to just work and getting things accomplished.

review_title: Bland corporate culture with a declining employee experience
pros: This organization is very large with mildly successful vertical integration. Headcount is adequate or close to it. Corporate is willing to invest in site operation expansion. With continuous growth there are opportunities for promotion.
cons:
Corporate doesn't seem interested in investing to provide adequate office space for employees when staffing new operations expansions. Employee retention is not given much priority. Office spaces are continually remodeled to cram more people into the same space. The company has little to no culture. Aside from the close proximity to your coworkers, the office spaces feel very "sterile". This is a bland company to work for. 

Salary and benefits are below average. You cannot roll over any PTO into the following year which seems like a tacky way for them to get deferred expenses off the books at EOY.

HR and IT are primarily outsourced so your local HR and IT resources will be overloaded. Corporate HR seems to only think about the remote sites once or twice a year.
Advice to Management
More frequent external salary comps. Expecting employees to take time to get outside offers just encourages them to leave. Hiring new staff is time consuming and expensive. Consider what your employee experience is like.

review_title: Good place to start, but not one to finish
pros:
- Starting pay and benefits OK
- Big company with wide reach so looks great on resume and some divisions offer potential for advancement
- You will work with great people and get exposure to all sides of the scientific business
cons:
- Too much bureaucracy; you will get people who you never met send you nasty emails 
- Company tries to run too lean and mean; employees (if they are not temps) often overworked and management will fight tooth and nail to hire people due to inter-company politics
- ERP systems are woefully inadequate and training is non-existent. Honestly disgraceful for a multi-billion dollar company and it results in angry customers
- High leadership turnover that results in disconnection; in my department, had 2 CEOs, 3 VPs and 4 ADs within a span of 2 years
- Company is getting too big and departments don't cross function well as result; also they take employees for granted and don't offer much in yearly raises/bonuses that do not even cover inflation
Advice to Management
Offer better health insurance, more % of raises, and more PTO; globoforce isn't enough

pros:
As with many biotech companies, your group, your manager, and your manager's manager will largely influence your (perceived) career trajectory and enjoyment. Fortunately, I've had two great managers so far, so my experience has been largely good. In my experience, the pros have been:
- Great people to work with. Most, if not all people in immediate surroundings work hard and carry their weight. 
- If you take initiative, you'll get plenty of opportunity to grow. 
- Drama is fairly minimal at the pre-managerial level.
- Stable job
- Technical teams are pretty lean
- Free coffee. You're gonna need it.
cons:
- Below average compensation. Annual salary growth is almost non-existent unless your position changes. 
- Employee retention is starting to dip.
- Many mandatory corporate-wide paperwork/training/assessments
- Many experienced technical employees refuse to take managerial roles, probably for a good reason...
- Pushing for change is slow in a big corporation, unsurprisingly.
- Career advancement is slow on average.
- Short-term (usually revenue-driven) goals eclipse the priority of investing in long-term process improvements.
Advice to Management
- Great managers REALLY need to be awarded more. They can make a big difference in retention, efficiency, employee growth and general satisfaction.
- Everyone is too busy to make PPI changes. Give your employees some dedicated time to make process improvements.
- Upper management should take time and listen to feedback from lower technical employees.

-absolutely zero room for career advancement unless you are one of the manager's "favorites" - managers will block applications to other departments or find ways to tell you you're unqualified
-daily expectations exceed department capabilities (i.e. running skeleton crew and being expected to produce as much product as 2-3x the current labor force could provide)
-managers do not care at all about employee's well-being, we are merely the means to an end (i.e. "I don't care, just get it done" type of attitude)
-excessive OT leading to burnout, management sees no problem in losing staff due to this but refuses to train or hire new people
-profits over people is the Thermo Fisher way. get used to having suggestions ignored or downright dismissed right to your face.
-morale is near zero due to the promise of *temporary* 10 hour minimum days and occasional weekend work that turned into 6 months straight of 50+ hour weeks and a half dozen mandatory Saturdays (and counting!)
-HUGE disconnect between office workers and lab workers, the people who sit at their desk all day have absolutely no clue what we go through back in the labs (although in their fairness, we have no idea how hard it is to send emails and go to meetings all day either).
-the HVAC system is a total joke. the office area is nice and climate controlled but the labs used to be a warehouse - there is no insulation or thermostats. facilities literally has to climb inside the ceilings to open or close the vents in order to let in more or less heat or AC. some rooms are 79 degrees F, some rooms are 58 degrees F. again, management says it's not a problem and we're just going to have to deal with it.
-for a $21 BILLION corporation, you'd think they could afford to properly compensate their employees but salaries are a JOKE compared to similar jobs in the surrounding area (like 25-50% less!) 
-HR is not helpful, mostly because there's only 1 person and she's got hundreds of employees to deal with so basically unless it's extremely urgent she's never going to reply.
-I could go on for days...I know I'm missing something
Advice to Management
wake up and start paying attention to your employee's needs! that means you actually have to get your butt out of your cushy chair, walk out of your nice air-conditioned office, gown up, and head back to the labs in order to talk with us about problems that need fixing.

review_title: Large company with matrix structure and opportunities
pros:
Profitable company 
Practical Process Improvement philosophy-always looking for ways to be more efficient 
Large company with opportunities for career development
Learn and leverage your finance knowledge; bottom line trumps all
Company measures diversity outcomes regularly

Nice employees and lower level management
cons:
Benefits can be better, subpar vision coverage
Matrix environment = politics
Difficult for new hires to learn how to migrate through a matrix environment- takes time to acclimate
Difficult to know who to go to and for what

Company says leadership behaviors are important but u fortunately more often makes an exception for someone if achieving desired profit
Company claims diversity important but No Diversity at top
Keeping cost low and driving profitability most important, regardless of people impact 
Sink or swim environment
Advice to Management
HOW management achieves outcomes should be equally important to profitability 
If Company committed to Diversity, then reflect at top levels

review_title: Upper management needed. Not a bad alternative to unemployment.
pros: Good salary/benefits. Regional managers and team are mostly excellent.
cons:
1. Management. Since the turn of the year upper management has been forcing more and more paperwork down our throats. It is to the point where we spend 30% of our time at a computer. The software is miserable and dysfunctional. After lots of problems and complaints, upper management decided to release a service pack to make it more time consuming rather than fix the bugs and time waste.
2. No Communication. The company has had multiple logistics nightmares this year in which the regional managers were not informed until their engineers started complaining. Chronically short staffed and customers of course take this out on engineers.
3. Completely disorganized company. You can not believe the disorganization and dysfunction. We have had lots of engineers from other large corporations come over and be shocked at how ridiculous it is. New employees take 6-9 months to start training and contributing, unless they quit first.
4. Morale. Morale is so low at this point that there will be large employee turnover. Only ones that will stay will be the ones that don't do much and like that they can get away with it.
Advice to Management
Help your employees serve customers. Support your employees rather than attacking us. Perhaps even try to figure out what it is we do? Organize, organize, organize to stop wasting millions of dollars every year. Honestly, just leave so we can get decent management.

review_title: In a Company This Large You May Feel Very Small
pros: Thermo Fisher is a strong, financially stable company and you can expect competitive benefits, but not top tier. They make an effort to provide a comfortable environment (decent cafeteria food and fitness centers) and show appreciation with events like BBQ's a few times per year and a nice holiday party (which was moved to Jan/Feb. I guess they want to save $ and not offend anyone?).
cons:
It's a huge company so you may not feel a sense of community. Profit is the bottom line. I saw changes that definitely didn't benefit customers and made day-to-day work more challenging for employees. Thermo Fisher acquires companies at a fast clip. You may be realigned out of a job or suffer in an understaffed situation. Growth & opportunities may be limited because job categories are pretty segregated by region/Country. Also, IMO wages are below average in Biotechnology.
Advice to Management
Invest in the people who make your companies run every day.

pros:
-strong management team 
-spend a lot of time training staff 
-wants employees to understand the business 
-good corporate culture where harmful interpersonal conflicts/bullying isn't tolerated
-every day you learn something about the products and the business
-B2B environment so 99.9% of customers are polite even when stressed
cons:
-on the customer service side, it's stressful 
-slow to change policies and adapt procedures
-long hours on the phone mean little movement from desk resulting in back backs, sore shoulders, and sore ears (always, always on the phone) 
-say they hire internally but a lot of excellent people got overlooked for promotions in favour of outsiders 
-you need to handle continual stress from high workload to stay at this job for more than 1-2 years. The customers are nice. Management is friendly. It's the workload and workflow that drain/burn out the customer service reps.
Advice to Management
-work to reduce the stress on customer service representatives
-work to upgrade computer systems 
-work on changing up daily routines so people aren't 100% on the phone. Good for a mental break. Good to give the ears a break too.

review_title: Quality products, decent pay and good benefits, dont care about employees you are only there to make profits
pros: The company has great quality products and the name of the company looks good in your resume. Decent sales training and co-workers are generally nice people and are supportive as a team.
cons:
Typical corporate-style management only cares about quotas and their bonuses. 
Expect you to talk to customers during business hours and expect you to work all evening on all follow-up office work. We are expected to be efficient with an extremely archaic and non-functioning CRM system that frequently crashes. Internal pricing teams and customer care are spread thin and overwhelmed with the demand of customers and orders. Management expects us, Account Managers, to be experts on thousands of products yet offer no training. There is a Technical Sales Specialist to work with but again are spread so thin we rarely get to work together effectively. 
Overall the company is too cheap to invest in internal updates to make our jobs easier and more effective yet they expect double-digit growth for each territory. 
Not a good place for diversity and do not understand other cultures and personalities that are not typical white American.
Advice to Management
Go into the field and interact with a customer, not every customer wants to buy every single thing from us. It is not really working in our favor to pressure us to sell everything. Customers tend to be standoffish when we mention the Thermo Fisher name due to the size of the company and the negative connotations of large companies. They really think we are the WalMart of science and not really helping with customer loyalty. 

Invest in your internal business processes because everything is so inefficient.

review_title: TMO Finance is toxic, favoritism, racism, political, hierarchy and disaster system
pros:
Ok salary and bonus with 80 hours/week workload expectation
15 PTO days include sick days
Work from home exists but for certain people only
ESPP exists but basically no discount
Ok benefits but they will push you to low cost HSA plan because cost is less
Average 401K match but you have to wait 3 months
Intensity is a scary word. The devil is in the detail
cons:
Intensity is a scary word there
Work Life balance is fake, certain people only
No fairness, only favoritism. You can do no wrong if management likes you. If you are not in that inner circle, just be ready to take all the blames even it's not your fault.
Racism heavily exists. Only one race will be promoted. They might put minority to unimportant spot occasionally just to show diversity, but never something meaningful position. If you are minority, female, colorful race or has foreign accent, you need to be quiet and obey, then you might have a chance.
Full of toxic culture. Few people will purposely speaking on phone so loud in open office space, so they can get attention from top. Also you will see few female employees constantly go to male director/VP's office to discuss "works" with door closed.
Backstabbing is real. This place doesn't care about your performance. Only what people say about you in the back matters. Be careful if you are smart and hard working, your manager and colleagues will not like it and they will try to take you down if you show too much ego. 
Finance system is just a disaster. You will be put into the place to create financial report with wrong data all the time. Watch out these people can talk intelligently about the system and data, they are the person with no clue but only really good in BS. But for some reasons, this company loves bs.
No job security. Be expected to look for new job every 1-2 years. They don't want you to stay at the same role too long. You need to go through the same interview process every 1-2 years competing with another 5 external candidates. That's their method to push out people they don't like without paying severance. 

If you are about to accept their offer but have another opportunity in hand, think twice. Make sure you know what environment you will get yourself into.
Advice to Management
Is there any management or HR?

review_title: Has grown too fast and too big - your just a number
pros: Great products, good mission and good benefits.
cons:
Company has grown too big too fast. In the final years it felt like people were just a commodity. Turnover of VP/GM's is alarming and the Global HR community has experienced massive turnover since the appointment of the current CHRO. Sad to see so many good leaders exit in the past 24 months. The culture has become cold and unforgiving. Personally I find this sad as I was such a cheerleader for the company for many years. But had to leave when I could no longer "sell it" to perspective employees.
Advice to Management
Remember it is the employees that made you successful. Need at least one member of the CLT to be balanced and comfortable with people and more importantly knows how to inspire. The tough approach of always finding fault even when the business is doing well is no longer working. Leaders are tired and burned out. Try a little praise and being visible - it goes along way.

pros: My division of Thermo Fisher is very proactive about safety and infrastructure. We receive finding for energy saving projects and efficiency projects. Diversity of thought still exists here - not just diversity of race. Both are present here. Upper management supports local initiatives.
cons:
Company is so large finding the right person or resources to complete a complex project is sometimes challenging. There are several divisions internal to Thermo Fisher that are very siloed from each other. Working on projects or getting support between divisions is difficult and almost never happens. I have had to remove sites from projects because they were from different divisions and have separate financial entities from ours. Not high wages but fair.
Advice to Management
Pay a little bit more attention to your employees and the amenities that are provided or talent will start to drift away to other companies that invest more in their Workplace & employee amenities.

review_title: Executive Assistant...worst company I’ve ever worked for!! RUN!!
pros: Great parking, good pay! Great cafeteria. New building.
cons:
• If you enjoy being part of a group of catty gossipy admin women, then this is the company for you. People say you get that anywhere you work, but nope I’ve never witnessed it quite like here!
• the upper management, or “4th floor” employees, are extremely rude, act well above others, and closed to new ideas.
• their only goal is to acquire as many smaller companies, to make as much money as they can - which I’m sure is the end goal for many businesses, but the over matrixed environment (the many companies rolled into one) makes working there unjustifiably insane.
• there is NO work/life balance
• HR is bias and not at all supportive if there is an issue with management. I have seen this work against people in many situations.
• CEO is one of the most over paid CEO in MA, and the BOD are pissed! Look it up, public knowledge. Greedy!
Advice to Management
Your HR group is horrendous!!! From the business partners, to the hiring process! I’ve never witnessed anything more unprofessional in my working career.
I helped interview executive assistant candidates, and then heard nothing but “unrelated” reasons why they weren’t a good fit for the job! Made me embarrassed to think that’s the hiring process I was once a part of. Shameful!

review_title: Criminally Low Salary; No Upward Advancement
pros: The work is often interesting and it is nice to be proud of the products we produce.
cons:
The pay is exceedingly low for Silicon Valley. If you're not an exec or, possibly, in sales, I hope you have a spouse with a high-paying job or have other income otherwise you'll struggle to afford the average rent here. 

There are few opportunities for advancement within the company. Though training is sometimes available for other areas as a means for advancement, the company rarely follows through on the advancement part. There are large groups of employees stuck in low-paying, go-nowhere jobs.

Management turnover is high. There are frequent power struggles among departments and communication is often poor.
Advice to Management
Pay your people an *actual living wage* for the area. The company makes, what, $1b a quarter now? You can afford it. This isn't some bootstrapped startup. 

Sort out the lab politics and work on improving morale within the entire company.
6 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: My boss and department were kind, but didn't get to have a say in what happened.

I was fired and I don't know why. I had a great boss and my department was really great. Repor

pros: modern facility with great cafeteria, variety of food options, the pay is also competitive, and some of the people there are nice
cons:
This company is toxic on so many levels. There's bias on management and endless toxicity aimed at females, minority and older workers. They try to promote diversity inclusion however, this isn't the case. The distribution of work is uneven, there are certain teams where the workload is unevenly distributed primarily amongst teams with minority, females and older workers. Be prepared to work 12-15 hour days almost everyday and on weekends. The salaries are great but the number of hours worked in addition to the added pressure to perform is not worth the money at all. There's a lot of insecurities within management and often those insecurities are taken out on the employees. Onboarding is basically non existing management wants employees to perform without proper training and understanding of the complexity of this company. Every year the company cuts the bottom 10% of its employees. If your salary is on the average range be prepared to receive low/no annual raise and low bonus payments. People are stressed angry and management usually take the anger out on the employees almost everyday. This company is also not flexible with allowing work from home even though the option is there but its frowned upon when you do. Finally most employees have 3 weeks paid vacation however, its impossible to request time off, be prepared to work on vacation or put in endless nights before and after vacation. Vacation time is also on use it or lose it basis, so the time can't be carried over. Finally your HR partner is not here for you, they don't care about you any confidential conversation will be sent back to your manager so be careful and trust no one. I've never experienced stress the way that I do working for Thermo, te people I worked with would throw me under the bus all the time. Stay away if you're looking for a normal life, good work life balance and balanced mental health. They also hire alot of external candidates and does not promote within unless you are chosen by management.
Advice to Management
Learn to pay attention to your employees, their stress level and train your staff so they can properly understand the complexity of the business. Focus on evenly distribute work flow and stop promoting diversity inclusion, talent until you've fixed the issue of toxicity and unfair treatment to females and minorities. To retain talent you MUST properly onboard and train your employees, Stop trying to have them figure it out. Promote your employees and stop making them feel like the work they're doing does not add value to your bottom line because it does (its reflective on the quarterly returns). The company has potential to be a great place to work but the stress and gender bias will ALWAYS drive your good employees to leave.

pros: I can put something on my resume
cons:
There is zero communication within the business, and it often falls on the lab. Schedules are chaotic, with turnaround times and expedites dominating the work to be done, which leaves large backlogs and disgruntled employees. Management is useless and despite communication, show very little willingness for change. Coworkers have been leaving left and right to escape, with no replacements and long wait times for approvals just to post a position, which leaves us highly understaffed. They dont want to hire people full time, even when contractors prove to have a great work ethic and strong drive. They also show resistance in promoting current employees, but will shovel on the responsibilities and workload of 2-3 people into one in order to save money. The building is falling apart, and all "fixes" are purely cosmetic. Benefits have gone down with the price going up, PTO got slashed, we are on average paid less than other sites within the same company in the same areas and IT is impossible to work with. The Cincinnati "Patheon, a part of ThermoFisher" site a dead end company to work for, and I would highly recommend looking anywhere else to keep your sanity intact.
Advice to Management
Organization needs to become a priority. If we arent communicating as a site to plan priorities outside of "we need this right now" and screaming matches, nothing will ever improve.

pros:
Pay is acceptable for the area, but should be negotiated prior to start date as there will be slow slow SLOWWW wage progress post hiring.

Despite operations being LITERALLY THE WORST PLACE I HAVE EVER BEEN EMPLOYED, R&D appears to be a great environment. In other words, as long as you avoid production roles you are probably fine.
cons:
-Metrics are everything. Which would be fine, if they were based in reality. 
-Constant stress and headaches over unrealistic goals. Moving goal posts.
-No opportunity for growth and advancement 
-Rampant favoritism 
-Promotions are not typically based on merit 
-Treated like a slave 

I was constantly told that "every corporation is like this" and "you should be more grateful, you have it very good here!" by people who have only ever worked in one place. 

Unless you want to spend your day getting reamed for walking around or taking too long of a break/lunch (OH! Don't worry, they'll time you) I would avoid this place like the plague. Find a normal job somewhere else, where they do real science.

Additionally, if you end up in production, some of the chemistry can be quite difficult. Following the batch record may result in failure. However when it comes time for bonus/promotions, you will be reminded that all you do is "follow batch records" and you don't "go above and beyond to make drastic changes to the process". Which of course you WOULD (updating batch records, etc.) if you had TIME. Which you don't.

Your personal goals are meaningless here, and management will straight up lie to your face about nebulous advancement opportunities just to get you to stay forever. Alternatively, they might straight up tell you that you do not do enough to move up. I'm guessing anyone less then a total savant is considered utterly useless.

Trying to train on processes is like pulling teeth. They are afraid to develop people, because they are worried they will lose them. The ideal employee here is barely smart enough to do the science, is willing to be treated like a blue collar worker, can work 2x faster than a normal human and is willing to lie to support the unrealistic goals.

NO JOKE. They actually discussed taping out a yellow square in front of the chemistry benches. You would have to be in this box a minimum of 8 hours a day, and any time spent away from your box (including bathroom breaks) would be unpaid. 

The philosophy here is "do more with less". That philosophy runs DEEP here. That is how they keep the margins on the products at 90% or higher. Personnel is part of the bottom line, so they are only interested in how to keep you down and keep you in the same role forever.

ASK AROUND! Some people have been here for 20-30 YEARS IN THE SAME ROLE. They are not stupid, they are not lazy, they just cannot leave due to having families etc. Thermo KNOWS THIS, and they take advantage of being the only large chemistry employer in the area.

I personally know of at LEAST 7 people who have had full on breakdowns due to the stress level here. There is NO WAY that is normal. 

I could go on, but I think I have made my point clear enough.
Advice to Management
If you do not see people as capital and continue grinding them to dust, you will be left with DUST. Then of course your greatest fear will come to fruition. You will have to do some work yourselves!

Remember you are dealing with smart, educated people. NOT COAL MINERS!

pros:

cons:

pros: None really. Decent benefits and 401K I guess.
cons:

Advice to Management
You have to reward, promote, compensate and recognize hard working employees who really stand out and are instrumental to whole new infrastructure development. You can't just lead them on and let them believe that one day they will be rewarded, recognized and promoted, and then lay them off instead. Don't just preach that you care about your employees, believe it and show it. Giving out free muffins or having a cookout doesn't show employees you care about them and it doesn't increase employee morale. After all, actions always speak louder than words!

Giving out free muffins or having a cookout doesn't show employees you care about them and it doesn't increase employee morale. After all, actions always speak louder than words!

review_title: Okay entry level job, management heavy, highly corporate
pros: Paycheque comes in every two weeks which is nice. Work life balance is okay but management is leaning towards more micro-management (aka the only positive aspect is being removed).
cons:
Awful pay. 

Bonuses are so low they are not worth the effort (example-customer surveys are weighted and gamed against the benefit of the worker so that any negative survey is weighted heavily enough to erase all the positive reviews and eliminate your bonus). They brought in some idiotic Thermo points system that you can overpay for merchandise rather than paying cash. 

Very corporate and very very management heavy. Vice presidents, managers, managers to the managers all with different goals that end up leading to less money, and a worse work life balance. Management themselves are incapable and the classic example of 'management.'

Zero chance for advancement or growth. This entry level job leads nowhere except to hearing your manager make excuses for lack of growth.

Publicly traded on stock market so management makes efforts to look like they're making progress despite the customers lack of desire to own the over-priced, highly unreliable equipment (all bad for the worker).

They do not take care of their staff. Would rather lose their qualified staff than compensate them fairly (high turnover).
Advice to Management
Stop being greedy. Fairly pay the staff that are on the ground in front of the customers. Offer stock options to staff.

Stop gaming the bonuses and reward system negatively against the worker (19 good surveys and 1 bad survey will equal an overall fail and no bonus plus you get a talk from your big brain manager).

pros: The work that Thermo Fisher does, what they make is important to the advancement of science.

Leadership is profit focused to a fault, expecting departments to handle growing operations while maintaining a flat budget.

Invest more in the people. pros:

9/80 Schedule
Job Satisfaction

cons:
antly evolving.
Checks don't bounce!
Cons

Lead Times too long.
Work / Life Balance can suffer.

Advice to Management

Spend more time on wowing our customers, and wowing our stakeholders will be easier.

review_title: Good pay + Team, Lacking communication and Efficient Direction
pros: Pays way more than the typical pay for similar job. Every person I come into contact with has been great. Benefits and insurance is great they paid completely for a lot of life ins. And my benefits only cost 100 with pretty much everything i could possibly ever need including a lawyer.
cons:
Horrible communication. Should know things way sooner than I found them out, still finding out. Theres no set standardized way of training so you know everything you need to. If something changes you have to hear it through the grapevine and not everyone hears it. Their system is subpar compared to others of a similar calabar in the field. I also dont foresee much room for growth. Only possibly one rung up when the person above me retires.
Advice to Management
Have more rigorous training with complete knowledge - instead of learn this for now and we'll teach the rest when you get this down(b.c that never happened until i screwed up.) Too many people telling me too many contradicting things. Complete lack of communication other than the basics. The details that matter get lost and arent thought of or arent told to us as a group. Maybe individual team meetings would help.

Also when you lose a manager. Hiring another would be great.
3 people found this review helpful

pros:
1.) Great Mission
2.) Opportunities to "Do your own thing." 
3.) Enjoy my colleagues
cons:
1.) Nobody is aligned. Feels like leaders at all levels (Groups, Divisions, Business Units, Functions) are marching to the beat of their own drum without regard to what the other is doing.
2.) In order to progress/be seen as a high performer, you have to assume multiple roles in the organization vs being given the opportunity to do one job really really well. This is okay for a season, but easily becomes the norm.
3.) We aren't competitive where we need to be from a compensation perspective. We say that we want to hire the best talent, but aren't willing to buy that talent.
Advice to Management
Continue to be conservative where it counts. Though this may be seen as a negative by many employees, this is why we remain viable. Take some time to reflect on what our competitors (direct, indirect, etc.) are doing to attract and retain talent. Doing things the way we've always done them will not result in attracting and retaining the best talent.

review_title: A decent company to work for
pros:
- Company has very good vision and values.
-Very noble mission of making the world healthier, cleaner and safer
-CEO is very capable and has achieved very good growth for the company
-Opportunity to work with amazing scientists who constantly push the boundaries of what’s possible 
-Very stable work culture - some employees have been there over 30 years
-Good 401k match and great benefits
-15-20 days paid PTO in addition to 10 annual holidays. Unused PTO can be cashed out when leaving
cons:
-Politics between teams and managers
-It’s hard to impossible to move within the company to different roles
-No free lunch and mediocre cafeteria food
-Very bureaucratic for IT requests, software development, HR processes
-IT policies are very backward - limited guest wifi access, only managers have access to start a web meeting, crappy antivirus that hogs your PC, clunky conferencing hardware. In this modern age, employees should be able to effectively participate in a meeting wherever they are and from any device of their choice.
- San Jose office building and facilities are from the 70s 
-Employees and managers seem to get promoted based on non work related activities such as community and charitable activities. These employees are given the center stage at company gatherings. Employees who actually get work done are taken for granted and get the backseat.
-Company is very stingy with resources even when they are profitable. It's a hassle to get approval for better computer hardware and technical training. Employees going on business trips are asked to drive instead of flying and share the same hotel room to save company money !
Advice to Management
To make the best products, you need to attract and retain top talent. Provide more avenues for employees to ask questions, provide feedback and move between roles without fear of retribution or bad politics. Don't be afraid to clean house once in a while and weed out the bad actors that suck the innovation and intensity of employees.

Invest in modern IT technology that enables employees to collaborate wherever they are and using any device of their choice. Improve the projectors and conferencing hardware instead of penny pinching on everything.
7 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Long work hours. Job stability. Free espresso machine. Great experience for new grads to learn something in the industry.
cons:
Long work days. Salary positions are horrible for 10-13 hour work days. Promotions happen to those that work long days. They maybe inefficient with their work load, but in eyes of management; they're hard workers. 10-15% paycut compared to it's competitors in Bay Area. Don't work here if you're trying to feed a family. But great place for new grads to take a paycut and learn industry work.
Advice to Management
Invest in your talent workers. Pay somewhat comparable to your competitors. Try to lower the attrition rate. Give lower management the head count they need to build the products. Standardize the GMP and not combine 3 different companies and product lines into one lab room. Atleast offer a free piece of pastry or muffin on Friday mornings to staff for their hard work. This is not a tech company like Facebook or Alphabet; however, you can afford to treat your workers with more respect. Please ask the manufacturing director to not say you can no longer afford to give out donuts at staff meetings when you generate over $20 billion a year.

pros: Challenging Work. Good Pay
cons:
Expectation is 50 - 60 hours per week. No upper management acknowledgement that we have home lives and families. Department did not honor corporate Flex Time Policy. Constantly driving us to "be the best" , but employees did not get professional training so they could improve or achieve. Only the contractors did. The favoritism toward certain members of the department was not at all veiled. Management would jump to conclusions without hearing all the facts. Corporate business partners were treated as customers; therefore, they were allowed to be abusive. They are not customers. They are business partners. We should be working together. With mutual respect, consideration and goals. The message management sent to them was that we were their doormats and they could abuse us all they wanted to. The message sent to their employees was "you are a commodity, nothing more."
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees. They know a lot more about what is going on than you do. Learn to respect your employees. Acknowledge that the job is not their life. Allow them to have a personal life. If they are allowed to rest once in a while they will perform better for you. Look at the crazy staff turnover in some departments. That is not on the employees, that is on upper management.
8 people found this review helpful

pros:
Most people you will work with are highly educated and knowledgeable. 
PTO time is good.
Benefits are good, especially health insurance.
cons:
Very cliquish. 
Toxic team environments. 
People don't matter, only revenue. They will work you until you drop even if they can afford to hire another body to help out.
Some very toxic leaders who contaminate those who report to them. 
Your performance is based on a comparison to everyone else's performance in your team/group even if you do completely different jobs and it is highly subjective.
Performance reviews are very old school and out-of-date, they don't help you to succeed.
Promotions are based on if your boss likes you, or if you are part of the "in" crowd, not based on your actual performance.
They don't help you succeed, and it sometimes feels like they purposely stand in your way of succeeding.
Getting what you need when you first start is a nightmare. 
Training? What training?
Diversity is highly limited in every way. Clearly it isn't valued because it isn't there.
Advice to Management
Stop with the "good ole boys" club and start to value what individuals bring to the table.
You don't need to run every single idea through tons of layers to get buy-in from the same people who all think the same way. You will never have any innovation or bring in new ways of doing things this way.
Break up the cliques! People want to feel like they belong at work, not just sit with their head down until they can go home.
18 people found this review helpful

pros:
Results always seem come out strong each quarter, which is great for shareholders and employee stock holdings; despite inefficiencies, ineptness, and layers of protected long service leaders who seem not to be accountable to delivery outcomes but drive up costs.

Carlsbad is a great location to be based
cons:
Downright inept leadership, a "yes" culture required up to the CEO, recycled leadership at the top levels that is change averse, closed to new ideas that can impact and contribute. 

Culture in LSG is toxic, people exit and are made to feel when they've resigned, and have money thrown at to retain, and still decide to exit, that they are now the problem. Retaliatory culture, and one where long standing/service relationships to the old boy network thrive.

Culture of keeping your mouth shut, head down, don't try to affect change, and that's the best way to survive and get promoted.
Advice to Management
Listen to those senior leaders you've hired in, they are a competitive advantage, but you ignore them and shut them out, and they leave and bring their competitive advantage elsewhere.

pros:
Stable company with decent benefits (medical, PTO).
Good camaraderie among colleagues.
On-site gym, sand volleyball court, multi-sport court, great coffee machines, reasonably priced lunch options on site.
cons:
Lots of opportunities to improve processes and the front line and supervisory staff want to make the improvements but no time to properly make them happen. 

Work Life balance is difficult as people work really hard to
Advice to Management
Need to balance priorities between revenue and employee morale/health better. A majority of employees work really hard, often making things happen by brute force so that the site can meet commitments. Employees are often exhausted but continue to grind it out day after day, this is not sustainable ... they are your most valuable natural resource. It's not always about wage compensation, it's about listening to those in the trenches and the need for process improvements (level loading builds, less reworks, streamlined processes/paperwork, etc).

review_title: Thermo Fisher Scientific- Fremont (Kato Road Location)
pros: TFS Fremont is huge and booming with the acquirement of many different smaller companies and products within the pipeline. It seems like the forecast is stable and the future is bright. Also, the manufacturing operations team (operator level) is one of the most hardest working group of people i've ever met. There is new management within operations that is leading the team to success.
cons:
With the wide variety of different products within the pipeline, I feel that the quality aspect of work is being neglected. The daily goal is to get product out the door, to satisfy customers and make dollars; but what about the broken processes that needs to be fixed? How can a multi-billion dollar company make so much revenue while the frontline operators suffer performing non-value added tasks such as the rework of lots and overtime on a daily? I don't blame the managers or the directors. I feel that it's a change that needs to happen beyond the SLT. Someone needs to step up and put safety and quality first before on-time delivery of product.
Advice to Management
Invest in the proper systems to get the job done such as a new ERP system, fix broken processes within the shop floor, focus on quality and safety before the delivery of product.

pros: Thermo Fisher Scientific is a growing company. The pay is good. The benefits are good. Some of the people who you work with are great.
cons:
The culture and leadership style are like the military. The boss tells you what to do, and you do it, no questions asked. Any comment that is contrary to what anyone else says is taken as a negative comment, even when you are not trying to be negative, but constructive. There is a true fear of having an open and honest conversation, as the discussion will be held against you. You will be labeled as "not a team player" and that is how people may talk about you. Once this happens, your time at Thermo is limited. They have a very high turnover rate. This is due to the fact that 1. they let a lot of people go, and 2. a lot of people want to leave due to the difficult culture. 

This leads to an unbalanced work / personal life. I typically work 12 hour days and some time on weekends. As they "reorganize," which is another name for downsizing, doing the same work with fewer people, the workload gets more difficult. Now their employment is growing, but you need to realize they are acquiring more and more companies. I had a woman work for me for 3 years, and she was happy and worked hard without me asking her to. She moved to a new boss who is more inline with the culture here, and she has been on the phone crying to me in the last 3 months several times. The sad part is no one can say anything to management or HR because then their job is in jeopardy. They are not a "team player." 

Last, one way they manage their cost is they let go of older talent, who also tend to be more expensive. They don't value the experience of the older employees, and thus, they just cut them to save the money. Then, they put someone with much less experience, or no experience in their place, and tell them to just do the job with minimal training.
Advice to Management
It is easy to look at the cost side of everything, but when you look at the value side, you have so much more potential for upside than just cost cutting. I understand that we are running a business, but people make up the business, and people will go the extra mile without the need for fear and intimidation. You set the culture, and the culture needs to change. There is a very hostile work environment for many people, and you can't hear it because they are afraid to speak up. They don't want to lose their jobs because they have bills to pay, kids to put through college, and many people don't like looking for a new job. 

I know it is hard to change, and there is a risk. The company is doing well and growing. So, messing with the culture could put that at risk. But, the human cost is too high. People need to be happy where they work, and not feel intimidated and fearful of their management. (I am afraid to click the submit button to post this here because of the backlash I might receive, even believing it is somewhat anonymous.)

pros: It used to be a great place to work. Good teamwork!
cons:
Senior managers that are completely unprofessional and disrespectful, yelling at employees on conference calls for doing their jobs. 

No career advancement. No real directions from senior IT leadership. A lot of dog/pony shows and buzz words but no real progress or understanding of how to reach goals.

If you were a legacy Pittsburgh employee you have no future with IT as is seen after *all* of the infrastructure managers were removed in the last 2 years. If you want to try for another job within Thermo, well good luck. 

If you are looking for work balance you will not find it here. Sure, IT operations requires a lot of hours and always has. But Thermofisher is completely willing to bury you day after day, every weekend, and holidays so that you can work on other peoples issues. They will berate you on technical calls involving 30 or more managers instead of letting you work with your service partner to fix the issue promptly.
Advice to Management
Management has forgotten 2 of the the companies core values. 
Involvement- you have not involved the Pittsburgh IT employees for 3 years! 
Integrity - The way you treat your employees is the exact opposite of integrity. So many very qualified IT staff members have left because of your utter BS that we are left with Life/new employees that are completely clueless.

Management is also willing to ignore its audit compliance and assume the risk of not completing key deliverables hoping no one will notice while snowing its external auditors. This started in 2016.

cons:
The pay could be a little more competitive in a department such as production as opposed to other pharmaceutical companies. The health insurance was changed this year and is not as good as what was previously offered.
Advice to Management
I have had nothing but positive experiences with management and my supervisor at this company.

pros: Friendly, genuine and hardworking teammates.
cons:
So much politics with local management; extremely high turnover rate, removal of employee’s many incentives, no transparency from upper managment; too many acquisitions but failure to incorporate different cultures; horrible treatment towards temporary workers/contractors. Management is constantly playing the blame games to cover up incompetency. Middle management’s sole focus is to please the higher ups. There is no people culture here, people are just leaving so fast, it’s impossible to build a culture. Pay is bad comparing to its competitors. Zero work life balance.
Advice to Management
Respect and appreciate your workers. High turnover rate means something is going wrong, acknowledge the issue, stop covering up your problems by pointing fingers.

pros:
Great product portfolio
Life Sciences Group operates in a new market full of potential
Great scientific minds come to work everyday in order to develop innovative solutions
Good place to gain experience for professionals, up to mid level management level
cons:
Quarterly Earnings drive decisions, even if it costs more on the long term.
Very senior management /executives lack necessary experience and competencies while arrogance abounds.
Culture of fear; Cult-like attitude towards CEO; highest ranking person in the room knows it all
Lack IT infrastructure to support size and complexities: not willing to make the needed investments
Advice to Management
Slow down and solidify/fix infrastructure before it all crumbles down. 
Seriously consider an attitude change and try caring a little for your employees.
The Board of Directors needs to change the Leadership team at the C-Suite in order to begin a change management process to create a humane culture.
It is a shame to have such wonderful opportunities and let greed cause to miss out on its potential long term success.

Can be a big, slow-moving company with archaic processes and difficult communication/poor organization simply due to its large size, various regional sites, turnover and past aquisitions. There is a gap between the 2 year seniority and the 10 year seniority. Senior leadership in some groups lacks skills to support/mentor/guide/manage properly. Can be frustrating if you want to be heard and make a difference or if you are joining to learn and accelerate your career. But it does depend on the team, group, division. Have brilliant scientists but also 9-5ers - most are probably just thinking of themselves or are burnt out. Just because it isn't a startup doesn't mean 9-5 ;P
Advice to Management
Take time to learn about your team, support what they want out of the position, enable new challenges, answer questions, provide guidance, mentor if possible, provide an environment for growth and happiness, lead by example, encourage learning at customer sites, other locations, classes, conferences etc.

pros: If you want, there is always something new and exciting to be a part of. There is an overall effort to strive for improvement.
cons:
Some of the systems in place are a bit archaic in nature. There is a huge disconnect/attitude difference between newer employees and senior employees. This often leads to many inefficiencies and many project being forgotten. Also, annual merit increases are often very low, averaging about 2%.
Advice to Management
Invest in your team and give people a reason to want to stay in their position for more than a year. There is a huge imbalance in the level of professional development opportunities between many groups.

pros: Medical Benefits and Wonderful Colleagues
cons:
The management style is "kick down" and "suck up" -- creating a hostile work environment for many employees. There is very little investment in good employees -- they pay low, don't promote, and don't encourage professional development. They also are unethical with how they develop and manufacture products, often sacrificing product safety and accuracy for a faster release to market. There is also very little support for commuters.
Advice to Management
Invest in your employees, follow ethical R&D development practices, create a positive work environment.

review_title: Data breach of employees' social security numbers & personal information
pros: Good at creating shareholder value
cons:
A third party breached company emails in mid- 2017. I was notified in April 2018 that my name and social security number were included in emails that were compromised. The company is offering 1 year of credit monitoring at no cost to the impacted parties. The notification stated that steps such as changing passwords were taken (presumably for the employees who had access to sensitive data and who also had their emails hacked).
Advice to Management
Invest in better security for the IT infrastructure. Compared to other large global companies I have worked for, the login system at Thermo Fisher is by far the easiest to navigate. I would rather type in a different code every morning than have my identity stolen.

review_title: Plenty of opportunity if you want it
pros:
Overall I have had an excellent experience at Thermo Fisher. When I was hired I felt insecure after a recent layoff at my previous company. Thermo Fisher has offered me tremendous opportunities for growth, which I took advantage of, and I am now leaving to go to graduate school armed with greater confidence and many more skills.

Some highlights:
1. Mentorship and interaction with executives - Directors and VPs were readily accessible and open to my questions about how their business worked
2. Education outside of Thermo Fisher - they sponsored several expensive graduate courses at Stanford, in addition to offering many other employee training opportunities
3. Access to new challenges - I consistently felt supported and challenged in my roles, and my previous managers wrote excellent letters of recommendation for me which helped me get into a competitive graduate program
4. Opportunities for advancement - in my first role, it wasn't obvious what my next job would be if I sought a promotion, but it's such a large organization, that there are opportunities everywhere. I think they make a significant effort to promote from within.
5. Work life balance - I worked in San Jose and Sunnyvale and at both sites I thought the work life balance was good for "professional track" employees. I did close to no work on weekends, and felt like my schedule was very flexible as long as I was achieving results. Working from home was usually an option, unless there was work I needed to do in-person on the products themselves (I'm an engineer).
cons:
1. Culture - typical of many major corporations. There's a significant amount of bureaucracy and it can be difficult to make changes even if the solutions are easy and obvious. 
2. Pay raises for hard workers - if you don't get promoted, your annual pay increase will be 1-2.5% MAX. My manager told me once, "if you work hard, you'll get a 2% pay raise, if you work really hard, you'll get a 2.5% pay raise." Which I didn't find very motivating.
Advice to Management
Allow more flexibility in offering pay raises to strong performers

pros: If you manage to survive longer than a month, you can consider yourself to be stress resistant and tough. There are no pros for the AP position.
cons:
The entire department is chaos, no one knows what they are supposed to do, 3 out of 4 managers are completely clueless and when put on the spot, they will dump all responsibilities on you.

You will not get support from manager, you will not get training, you will learn by making mistakes and being blamed for it.

Managers and HR are intrusive, they will monitor your personal life, your breaks, doctor appointments (I had to wait a week before being given the time off and I was asked to provide the reason).

Managers will use scare tactics to make you work overtime and weekends (extending your probation period, shouting at you, asking you if you really want this job).

Workload is unbearable, you will be doing the work of 2 people, which means that you are bound to forget to do things or running out of time, you will be blamed and asked to provide full details on why and how you could have possibly forgotten something, while all the things you are doing well are completely oblivious to the management.

The department is badly organised, management is not aware that computers have been invented, you will print everything and archive it in a box, there is no database, only the boxes in storage. I have spent hours looking for a piece of paper which could have been scanned and stored in a database. Thermofisher is not a green company, you will spend your days printing.

I worked for 7 months and I know of 6 people who suffered from burnout, some people came and left within a week. They are 25 people in the team.
If you are asked to give suggestion on how to improve the department, do not answer, it is a trick question, you will be reported to HR for having a negative attitude.

The company is located in the middle of nowhere, if you don't have a car, it will be difficult to get to work, you can take the bus, emphasis on THE bus, there is only one which runs once an hour, if you miss it, you have to take a taxi which will cost 10 pounds. The bus is always full, be prepared to stand.

You can take the job if you are desperate, my advice would be to keep looking for something else, the department will not get better as long as the managers are there.
Advice to Management
Treat people like human beings
Organise yourself
Get an understanding of the job that your staff does, you can't tell people what to do if you don't understand it yourself

pros:
-intensity: fast-paced environment, constant multi-tasking
-colleagues: I have met some great, supportive people here
cons:
-Intensity: this element of company "culture" makes for a terrible (non-existent?) work/life balance. I regularly work 10-12 hours days and keep waiting for it to pay off or my hard work to be recognized. Still waiting...

-Stress: As a young person in their 20s, I feel my health suffering from this job. The stress and lack of time for exercise, personal care, and mental health have definitely shaved off multiple years from my life.

-Site: I work in Carlsbad and the site culture is terrible. There is no HR presence as far as site events or moral goes. I know it's a huge site, but they make no effort and it's very obvious.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees' survey results! It's great to drive an intense culture and attract the kind of employees who thrive on that buzz, but it is absolutely CRUCIAL to strike a balance. If you mean to retain talent or build employee loyalty and longevity, management needs to address this.

review_title: Consider carefully before joining as you might get easily frustrated and create problems for yourself
cons:
der carefully before joining as you might get easily frustrated and create problems for yourself
18 Feb 2018 - Anonymous Employee in Horsham, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Not much to say that is positive
Cons
Dishonesty ,cowardly and two faced behaviour from line management - no feedback and communication. Not once did my line manager offer and arranged a 1 to 1 meeting to discuss or manage expectations or if there were existing issues so watch your back. 

By then they will go straight to senior management or HR to be involved just to intimidate you when it could be handled more softly.

Face fit and blame culture - they will try and find every little fault about yourself and discredit you no matter how petty it sounds as to why you don't fit. So make you feel its your fault and humiliate you bordering on racial discrimination.

Disjointed systems meaning work duplication and poor data management. There are not the most efficient at managing their data and storing.

Office is near a landfill site so you need a car to get there but car park in poor condition - I had 3 punctures all with nails stuck in my tyre whilst working there.

I heard that the person who took my role also left very shortly afterwards. 

If you are use to fast pace , high intensity and very proactive environment then this is not the company for you because you will always feel you're being held back when trying to get things done by the bureaucracy and the internal politics.
Advice to Management
Being honest and providing regular feedback and setting goals and expectations would have been a good start and formal 1 to 1 meetings

review_title: LSG finance is not a happy place.
pros: Base Salary and bonus are pretty good. Med benefits are standard. 15 Days of PTO which technically includes your sick time, but “working from home” when sick does happen. ESPP exists, but discount is smaller than usual. Really nothing overly special other than that it is a large stable company.
cons:
Hard to progress with the amount of favoritism taking place. Even then, they seem more likely to hire from outside than promote from within. Deadlines are often unrealistic. All of their financial systems and data are a disaster. They acquire or restructure their businesses so frequently that it often makes any financial analysis so confusing as to be nearly worthless. Unless you are a director (with an office), you will have zero personal space. You will be seated in a huge open floor, in blocks of six seats, three per side. You will feel like your elbows are basically touching the people next to you, and you can see the people across from you... and that’s just within your block. It didn’t feel like finance was very appreciated there, even within finance, and there was just a general undercurrent of insincerity surrounding everything, especially performance reviews. If you are happy with you current employer, and your happiness is more valuable to you than whatever pay bump you might get here, then I’d recommend staying put.
10 people found this review helpful

pros: Thermo acquired us. Kept us as such for about a year. Not necessarily the best thing but not the worst for everyone.
cons:
They weren't honest about who was being kept. They cut 60% of our site and got rid of it. They were never honest about their plans. Those that were let go weren't given explanations as to why. Many senior people let go and many senior people not given chance to talk to other managers or seek employment in mirror groups. They just did not care. They actively avoided us and even sent emails that got around specifically saying we were not welcome at this other site. They cut a lot of very knowledgeable people and showed no decency about it. It made me happy to leave.
Advice to Management
What can I say? HRs will never tell the truth and be honest. Advice always goes in one ear and out the other. They ignore their employees and just care about the best interest of the company as if employees are NOT the company. There is nothing they can do about it and nothing they will do. I even dealt with harassment. There were bold admissions from the guilty party and they still did nothing.

pros: Thermo Fisher is a good company to work for. The environment is friendly and relatively low stress. Most employees are offered a flexible work schedule. There is opportunity for advancement. Community service is encouraged and they even give you paid time to volunteer. They also offer employee resource groups and career development workshops. The Pittsburgh office building is nice with a cafeteria, gym, and free parking. The benefits are very good with excellent health care and 401k match.
cons:
Thermo Fisher is so close to being the best company to work for as mentioned in the pros. The only real negative is pay. It is below industry average and only upper management receives any bonus pay.
Advice to Management
Bringing pay up to industry standard and adding incentive pay for all full time employees would make Thermo Fisher a top tier employer. It would also provide additional motivation to meet business performance targets. Overall though, management does a good job of making employees feel valued.

- Meal allowances too low

review_title: Don't spend more than 1-2 years here
pros:
Good pay and benefits but you'll eventually find out that it is not worth staying for

The company's name- do not stay here for more than 2 years. In some positions-You will not learn anything
cons:
Unless working in the lab, not a good place to work if you have a science degree. If you do have such a degree, do not take tech support and customer service positions. In tech support, about 70% of what you do is customer service work. Do not believe the job description. You've been warned. 

Favoritism by management and throwing newer employees under the bus as well as taking advantage of them. 

Managers/supervisors with no backbone

Incompetence beyond belief, highly disorganized, nepotism, top heavy, and the company is too big for its own good. No company culture. 

Bitter employers. I have coworkers who think that because they have been with the company for so long that they don't have to do anything and management is aware. More seasoned employees will not share all that they know with newer employees in order to hold on to their job security. There are ppl who have held the same exact position for 20-30 years. There's no real cross training. 

Useless onsite HR. Have to contact offsite HR for everything.
Advice to Management
Please treat all employees fairly or they will not stay, regardless of the benefits you offer. Please structure your departments in such a way that employees' skills are utilized and that they are not doing work that they are way too over qualified for.

cons:
Location - quite remote and cannot be reached by public transport and also right next door to a very smelly landfill site; office space is claustrophobic (large open plan office with no windows); inequalities in salary amongst people doing the same work; very rigid processes which can make it frustrating to get work completed; working at home outside of core hours is often necessary in order to keep on top of work load (see previous comment)

Addressing the salary issues will go a long way toward improving the staff turnover

review_title: Feels like I go to work in the film "Brazil
pros:
My co-workers for the most part are skilled and dedicated. 
The technical challenges are often interesting.
cons:
Worrying every day about the stupid decisions management is about to make.
Watching dozens of co-workers get laid off, year after year, and never replaced.
Being told to "work smarter, not harder" and then being given meaningless mandates in place of work that provides value to our customers.
Watching our loyal customers be dragged along for years thinking we'll take care of them eventually, while they're being written off internally as not being worth supporting. Then watching them despairingly go to our competitors and find they provide real solutions.
Advice to Management
Give a damn about the people who actually do the work, and not just the shareholders. 
Or, sell off the business to someone who will.

pros: In my experience, Thermo Fisher pays well, supports employees to a reasonable degree, and shows loyalty to its employees. Upward mobility is encouraged and managers will hire within the company whenever possible.
cons:
Thermo Fisher is a large and corporate. The downsides of this should be obvious: navigating the bureaucracy can be tedious, and a certain amount of self-direction is needed because people stay busy and may not be able to assist with every issue. But that being said, I only had to make minor adjustments to make this work.
Advice to Management
1-Keep recognizing and rewarding good work in employees. Employees who work well are often promoted or recognized in some way, which gives extra incentive for the employee to do their best. 2-Cut the dead weight; the loyalty to their employees can sometimes be abused by lackluster employees.

pros: I came aboard just after Thermo merged with TF. Kept me in work during the depression. A lot of great talent there. I beat the cuts year after year. Cross trained in multiple areas taking on workloads from lost workers not being replaced. The gym was fun -indoor volleyball/basketball/racquetball showers and trainers. They demolished existing buildings (also the gym) to cut cost and jam us all together. Very cool to see all the academics in engineering and product development-they had expensive cars really cool. Too bad that $$ wasn't shared with those whom make the Wall Street expectations.
cons:
I worked there 9 years and had 11 managers in that time. Just when the new MGR understood enough they would go or be fired. Add the lean / kaizan projects on top of a yearly PMD with stretch goals-really-Not everyone wants to go go go every year. It's just a JOB. Others leap frog around office/plant politics politics politics. CEO would stop by when the division was slacking-not so much when doing well.
Advice to Management
Allow four day work weeks. Oh that's not possible with the lack of steady paced work. Difficult to work stress free when everything comes down on Thursday and fridays. The heaviest month is the last in the qtr. hockey stick effect in full effect year after year. Heaviest end of qtr to meet/beat last qtr-great for the guys that make commissions. Not so great for those in the trenches.

review_title: A bit of luck, a bit of hard work, and a lot of playing the game
pros: We have the opportunity to make "uncapped" commissions, but in order to do so, you must understand the pay plan. There is a flexible work schedule that allows you to adjust your days to best fit your needs. There is freedom in your role to take advantage of traveling opportunities, networking events, and trade shows, but this is mostly based on favoritism or the territory you are assigned (not necessarily your achievement). When you start you receive 15 days of PTO to be used however you want.
cons:
Blankly put, the pay is bad. You will get paid very similarly to your counterparts, no matter the size of your territory. If you make $3M in profit for the company, you will make the same as a rep who is only required to make $1M. You make your year's salary in one week and then rake in money for the company with seemily no payout as a sales person. Our pay plan pays cents on the $10,000.
Advice to Management
Relative to peers in our same job roles at other companies, we make much less. Most of our work feels like customer service and not necessarily sales. A lot of opportunities are rewarded to individuals who are viewed in a negative light by their coworkers. The work can be very unfair in the department with many people doing a ton of work and others getting by with huge accounts that require no hand-holding. A lot of seasoned reps just do well enough to get paid and don't want to work too hard, knowing that next year you are forecasted based on this years' achievement. This creates laziness and a very bad environment for new reps who want to move up and out. Everyone knows that you will only make more money if you leave the company, and it is encouraged by the amount of turnover in the department (over 1/3 of reps have been with the company less than 2 years).

Thermo Fisher leadership at large needs to examine why there is so much turnover, churn and dissatisfaction within the IT organization particularly within shared services.

pros:

Large firm with multiple business units allow for more opportunities

Driven and high performing employees
cons:

Extremely Clique-ie
Timelines are unreasonable
Process Improvements fall on deaf ears
Say their is opportunity to take other positions, good luck if your not an FLDP
Raises are pitiful. Ask for a higher salary from the get go or you will wind up under paid in a year or two

Stop treating non-FLDPs as nobody's. Non-FLDPs have things to offer as well, provide non-FLDPs with projects that are meaningful, not the left over stuff no one wants to do.

Invest in integrating your financial systems, stop acquiring firms and not integrating them into the over all organization

pros: Good location, wage is fair and most people are friendly. There were some good bonuses and there was more than adequate parking.
cons:
There is a culture of continual improvement which in itself is good. I just felt that some of the meetings were time wasting really; just to fulfil the corporate expectation of analysing all processes to save time and money. It felt like having meetings for meetings sake. There was even a feeling of deja vu as somebody actually said, 'Didn't another team resolve this issue last year'!! A team did spend time looking at it but few of the initiatives seemed to have been carried out.
Also some of the staff here were difficult to work with as there was a clique mentality in some departments with a lot of back biting. There was a lot of legitimate complaints about some members of staff but no headway in resolving the issues as the bullying just carried on.
Advice to Management
Stop the constant nit picking continuous improvements where some members of staff have to sit on 3 teams a year to fulfil a personal performance review. Just think about the time wasted when some people just don't want to be there when they could be more productive just doing their job.

pros: LARGE company with opportunities to move.
cons:
HR is not involved with employees and there are some leaders that are only interested in numbers. When there is an issue with a manager, HR is nowhere to be found. I worked there for 6 years and had 5 managers. My last manager did not treat me fairly and I was out. I know of 3 other employees that ended in the same way with different managers. All in the same discipline. No warnings, no corrective actions, no good reasons. Lastly, when an employee survey from the group came back with low scores, the employees were gathered and asked to re-submit the scores. One of their core values is supposed to be integrity. They didn't ask why the scores were low and instead gathered the group and asked that we rethink our answers. That is not integrity in my book.
Advice to Management
Listen to employees, not just the managers. If a whole group is having issues, maybe it's the manager. Encourage honesty to foster improvement. Have HR act impartially so the employee has a voice. You have lost a lot of talented people because of a lack of a voice upwards.
