review_title: An Example of a Broken Truly Dysfunctional Company
pros: There is no Pros at all, maybe free fruits and good cafeteria
cons:
Don't know where to start, my advice to you is just stay away from this place. The most dysfunctional company I ever worked at. Nothing is in its place and work right. There is no system in place. High turn around with no permanent HR or IT. Toxic culture and Gang-Like, only lazy incompetents fit in this culture.

In R&D you get to do the most boring task on the earth, trying to come up with an idea for an assay and you will continue to work on that for a while like 2 years, then you get scrutinized for example because it doesn't sell as well or there is a better product out there.

Very Very incompetent manager (Directors), who only want to keep their job and a friendly incompetent employees. R&D staff have a very toxic "click culture" who only gets a long with incompetent low motivated employee of their own kind. 

No good product is made in Thermo Fisher Scientific. They have people with no experience who are working on things they are just learning about.

No development opportunity is provided to R&D employees. Director constantly on his own pleasure off time (god knows where) and employees are forced to work over time to finish projects on their set deadlines.

You have to work 24/7 to keep up with their non-functional tasks/deadlines and you wont be appreciated at all.

Just do yourself a favor and stay away from this place.

review_title: Stay away - please don't waste your time here
pros:
Good if you work at their Carlsbad or Waltham location, as the leaders only promote within that inner circle.

Industry leading brands
cons:
Leadership will never WALK the TALK, especially the annual "farcical" employee involvement survey, it is the most hypocritical input/output process. only pockets of leaders take it seriously, else this Company is a finance driven company (read top line and bottom line impact) and don't be waylaid by any of their PR campaign or propaganda about saving lives/ making a difference in healthcare or the foray into precision medicine. 

Jobs at few of their sites being outsourced to Lithuania. 
Inner circle of decision makers primarily comprised of middle aged caucasians patting each other's backs and will never reinvest in their fragmented IT infra and equipment infrastructure, as it is an extremely " profit-driven" culture. 
Demoralizing way of developing and engaging millennials : another classic example of "your new innovative ideas" may have worked at your previous employer, but this is the way it always works here. 
And they only talk about SMART goal setting for all employees: however goals are ONLY set ( sorry shoved down) to APPEASE finance VPs and Corporate execs. 

Lots of examples of " fake it till you make it" especially at the VP level 
No wonder there is attrition at every level.

pros: Takes on relatively inexperienced staff and trains them, it's a place where you can start a career and gain experience. Always opportunities to get involved with internal projects, make a difference and get your name out there. Staff on site are pleasant and make it a good place to work. Change management is reasonably well done and at a good pace.
cons:
Culture of bullying is present throughout the business unit from the top down so very hard to get away from. You are often made to feel like you should feel fortunate to work there as you're not good enough to get a job elsewhere - that sort of thing. Micromanagement is rife and employees are always physically watched by their manager, there is little trust in that way. It feels a lot like school, I once got told off because I had my elbows on the table and desk inspections took place to ensure you were being tidy. I felt this had no place in an office of highly experienced, degree-level professionals. 
Remuneration is low and below industry standards but the company knows this and this is their approach so negotiate what you are happy with up front. Appraisal system is harsh, requires a lot of work from the employee but it is fair and you are measured directly against your peers, the better you do the better % pay rise you will get but expect about 2%. Poor performers will need to improve fast or expect to be managed out. 
Although change management is done well overall employees are not listened to if they want to raise concerns. Workload was very high and most staff were considerably overloaded. No-one left the office on time.
Advice to Management
Stop the bullying culture. Listen to employees. You have such good people, look after them!

review_title: Great Company, Great Job, Great Benefits, Witchy Boss
pros: I enjoyed my job, work-life balance, the compensation, facilities, my co-workers, company culture, and the company in general.
cons:
I heard a lot of criticism about my work and performance but little to no praise for it. First example, my manager was out sick for a couple of days. On my initiative, I posted a large note outside her cube to let people know. When my manager came back in, she was flabbergasted that I had done such a thing. Yes, she used the word, flabbergasted. She chewed me out for about 10 minutes. She claims that she told me not to do that before, but I do not remember the conversation. Second example, my manager called my work on an operator manual a failure. Yes, she used the word, failure. She pointed out specifics. I pointed out some things I did correctly in the document, but that did not seem to matter to her. When I asked my manager why I did not receive any compliments from her about my work, she did offer one, but I have not heard another compliment since.

I did not feel that I contributed to the company much. For example, my manager read and provided feedback on everything I wrote including some of my email messages. Although her feedback was valuable and improved the documents, I feel that things might have gone faster if she simply did the work herself. She often complained about how much time she spent redlining my work.

I did not feel that I was allowed to think for myself or take initiative in solving problems. For example, my manager asked me to resolve a conflicted files problem in our software versioning and revision control system. I asked a co-worker to help me, and we spent some time on the phone to resolve it. He seemed happy to help me, and we solved it. Afterwards, my manager told me not to waste his time and that every work-related problem I have should go through her first. She also called that co-worker to apologize to him for wasting his time, which I did not feel was necessary.

review_title: Take the Good When You Can
pros:
-Good local health benefits for Pittsburgh employees.
-Generous PTO with the option to buy an extra week (there is some murmurs about sick time not being a separate bucket, but compared to other companies of the same size and history, it's pretty good)
-There is general stability of the company as a whole.
-They've really pushed to start to help people understand their own career development. Some of the tools and speakers that are provided would be expensive to source ourselves.
-There are allotted volunteer hours, if small. And donation-matching for certain charitable efforts.
-The new maternity/paternity leave is impressive.
cons:
-TFS still pays below the median in Pittsburgh and it will only be more evident as larger and more progressive companies come to the area. Having good health insurance is great and I am grateful, but it isn't as attractive to younger employee that is trying to build their life and pay their student loans.
-Annual raises are abysmal and below even typical COLA, so employees are constantly moving laterally to try to get ahead. This means that there are rarely people that want to improve their current roles past what it would take for them to move to another role. 
-The facilities are in the middle of nowhere and there is no public transit access, so you must have a car. This alienates a portion of viable candidates that aren't interested in the expense of a vehicle or can't afford it. Pittsburgh's budding metro area will only propel young professionals to have a lifestyle without a vehicle and look elsewhere.
-There are silos and divides everywhere that leads to very few people that are cross-functional. There is animosity between those employees whose work is considered more transactional and those whose work is considered analytical. The push is to consolidate the transactional work without really thinking or validating that those employees are producing the majority of the viable results. When things go wrong, there are no subject matter experts to work through the deltas. And something always goes wrong.
-The push for updating tools is commendable, but the tools that are being updated are the least important. There are inventory and order-intake tools that are decades old, but the company is focused on a facebook-like communication tool. Why?
-Diversity is touted, but hardly practiced as the band level increases.
Advice to Management
-If there is any contingent that is going to be in Pittsburgh in the future, it is important to instill trust into those employees that are integral to the processes that have been in place. The median age in most departments is alarming. Who is left to impart the knowledge to to actually complete tasks and not just analyze how efficiently they're being completed?
-Better raises mean happier employees that want to make their departments better and more productive. 
-ERGs are awesome, but only if their values are being practiced throughout the company. Diversity is more than just a word.

pros:
- Like the tech stack and opportunities provided to rise and shine
- Emerging Technologies Teams are very energetic. Great open culture
- Very flexible work schedules. Easy to strike work life balance
- Employee feedback is taken seriously by ET Senior Management
- Teams are encouraged to share and learn from each other
cons:
- lot to improve on hiring tech leads and first time managers.
- HR is very negative. Need world class HR talent if we envision to be most admired company. Everything else is improving but this is a big drag
- Unnecessary and bloated HR Org - partner, manager, country, TA, Administrative HR. Employee ends up with confusion on why there are so many roles for a simple HR function. Each simple query or decision takes years and mostly results in a negative outcome due to incompetent handing.
Advice to Management
Improve Policies with sole focus of becoming most admired company.

Hire capable HR talent who have progressive outlook. They need to shed negative and pessimistic approach. 

Lean, technology-enabled, well-trained HR teams are able to take advantage of modern talent practices and partner with business leaders to drive impact.

review_title: Great place to work, if you don't want to progress
pros: Great people who work hard, collaborate, and generally feel good about what the company does for the advancement of the overall environment, safety, and health of animals, plants, and humans.
cons:

No real trust at the director and executive level to empower team members to make decisions and move forward. Lots of micro-managing and second guessing. Very Very Very slow to make a decision.
Advice to Management
Stop with unrealistic timelines for delivering projects. Appreciate employees not just by a mention, rather through more action. If you're willing to throw money to make a project move faster (but isn't a reality that it will move faster) be willing to consider more reasonable timelines, resources, and career accolades first.

pros: zero or very few pros in the AP team
cons:
- Accounts payable workload is not managed properly - many people doing the minimum and few people (generally foreigners working very hard )
- AP department is run like a old fashion small factory where the manager is allowed to abuse and bully the new employees
- Lack of basic knowledge on finance, accounting and IT
- Bad attitude of management generate unpleasant employees and constantly people talking in the back of their colleagues
- your capabilities are never recognized (often manager hide your skills from other manager to don't feel ignorant )
- Back stabbing is the rule
- Several people calling sick for stress for weeks or even months
- Managers can't handle the pressure from their bosses and all responsibilities and faults are passed directly to the new starters 
- No career progression and very high turnover rate - I saw more than 10 people leaving in a team of 25 in 1 year (some colleagues resisted only 1 month )
- Non transparent behavior from manager and a lot of politics within the team 
- Terrible canteen, no decent employees areas, no multicultural awareness 
- All employees are demotivated by manager's attitude
- New project are terribly handled and the lack of organization skills from AP directors and Team Leader makes the workflow slow and confusing
- No respect for personal/private issues 
- Unless you are in the "lucky group of people" you need to ask half day off even to go to a Dr appointment (different story if you have the right connections )
- It is a place where you learn wrong procedure and you can't improve yourself: it will bring down your skills
Advice to Management
HQ should take responsibility of all these issues and redesign the management structure replacing old style unproductive people with forward thinking, skilled and dynamic people. Also HR should educate managers on how to deal and respect employees maybe organizing people skills related training OR encouraging the employees to report abuse, shouting, bullying etc

review_title: If it's broke, don't fix it
pros:
I always had a good manager, but that is not universal across the company.
I had a lot of opportunity to travel all over the world, which was interesting (before Thermo travel policies kicked in)
I worked with a lot of smart, hard-working people that I liked.
cons:
I was not stretched too thin, but colleagues across the organization were, which made it difficult to get things done (want legal to review a simple MTA change? Give it a week or two... have a question for someone in AP or procurement? Good luck.)
New travel (expense) policy is a joke. I'm not going to eat at McDonald's or Applebees when I'm traveling for work.
Cheap. Old. Paucity of women in leadership positions. Purely transactional HR function.
Plenty of people who were simply incompetent and should have been given the boot or moved into roles for which they were better suited. Maybe this was just an issue with leadership within my business unit, but it was a strong driver for me to leave.
All companies exist to make $, but that is all that matters at Thermo. If the're not making it, they're squeezing it out of the businesses and employees.
Advice to Management
Management, like everyone else, you too will be happier if you leave Thermo.

pros:
Big company so basic benefits taken care of (though sometimes expensive)
Leading manufacturer of biotechnology's most essential products
cons:
Goal of management is to optimize not just their products, but also their employees to their maximum - unaware that people are not robots, and burn-out is a thing

No real innovation - since culture is of acquiring companies to become an Amazon of sorts for biotechnology, they buy the tech and scale it as high as possible, quality be damned

Health insurance is expensive

Goals are for show, moving up is quite difficult in the provided structure.
Advice to Management
As part of the San Diego Affymetrix acquisition, most were excited at the prospects and opportunities a big company would bring but also for professional development. However, Thermo killed the once vibrant, family-like stick-together into one of each person for themselves, in less than a year. It's corporate in the biggest sense. All innovation or self-motivation taken out of the picture so employees are forced to focus on extreme deadlines with no time, or real incentive to help each other out.

Tone-deaf decisions with no employee satisfaction in mind: not going to succeed by providing a few Town Halls to vent his concerns. No transparency, unnecessary relocation to Carlsbad away from a biotech hub into a cramped space, false incentives when there's no hope of promotions, same below market eBioscience salaries. 

Overworking employees because some guy in a suit somewhere arbitrarily picked some numbers to meet unaware of mfg groundwork. Layoffs were awkward. New leadership has no idea of culture and makes no effort to understand, leading to people not being utilized for their strengths. Conversations need to be more intimate, stepping out of their offices but that's if mgmt actually wanted to act on these concerns..

Senior leadership needs to really examine how they are taking decisions. You can make us read endless acronyms and Thermo's "values" but end of the day, if your really want efficiency you have to mutually provide to employees; or else a thriving, collaborative group quickly falls apart ...and takes their expertise elsewhere...
3 people found this review helpful

pros:
Nice, low key, relaxing environment to work in every day. Work is always "work" but working in a park like setting where everybody is casual and relaxed makes a big difference. The location in Carlsbad actually includes a park, an opportunity to get outside in the sun during breaks. Felt like working on a nice college campus and this contributes greatly to the overall feeling of going to work there everyday.

Generally uses state-of-the-art business platforms so this is a good place for upgrading your technological skills in the business world. It is a paperless company.

Not a lot of perks, but lots of freedom to get out of the office and walk around outside, which may sound funny but is actually a HUGE perk in terms of getting through the work day and enjoying where you work. I loved their beautiful park and campus and took full advantage of this while working there.
cons:
They use a lot of contractors to keep costs down. Not so easy to get a permanent position, but is still a very good way to upgrade and update your skills or learn new skills that will help you advance in your career.

review_title: Company doesn't live up to its 4is (Integrity, Innovation, Intensity, Involvement), has a high cryonism culture.
pros:
Medical benefits were OK. Seem comparable to others in the area.
401K match 
3 weeks paid time off.
Large global organization with the ability to work with people of a variety of backgrounds.
cons:
High cronyism culture - meaning that people are hired and promoted based on their connections and close friendships with others in the organization (not necessarily based on ability).
Salary is very low. Often is at the low end of the market. Yearly increases are very low, sometimes not even enough to cover cost of living. How do they expect someone who is making $15/hour to survive on this wage? This results in a lot of turnover. 
Managers expect salaried employees to check emails at night and over the weekend to get things done. Often managers send requests last minute and expect an employee to work on it over the weekend. Work life balance is OK for some, but not others. 
Culture of constant layoffs to meet $$$ numbers driven by corporate. Instead of consistently delivering layoffs, they should be hiring competent managers who know how to manage their employees and know when to let go of under performing people.
Culture of throwing people under the bus is definitely prevalent. People do not own up to their mistakes and responsibilities, but rather blame others. So much for the value of integrity.
Lack of communication from senior leadership/management to employees and departments are often siloed.
Managers tend to do a great job of managing up, but do not know how to properly manage their own employees. 
Responsibilities and expectations are not clearly defined for employees. 
Lack of employee recognition. Often employee's hard work goes unnoticed and is never recognized. Sometimes employee's don't care about monetary rewards as much as they would appreciate being recognized for their efforts. 
Lack of career development conversations with management. As mentioned above, it is a high cronyism culture, so many employees who were promoted were just buddies with higher ups. 
No sick time offered 
No perks like other companies in the Silicon Valley. If you're going to try to compete with other companies in this area, you need to do a major overhaul on your company culture and company perks. Thermo offices in the Silicon Valley are stuck in the past and how things were done years ago. 
There is an employee survey every year, and management doesn't do a good job of actually making lasting long-term improvements. Instead, they put band aids every year to make it look like they are doing something to better their employees.
Advice to Management
Company culture has to change drastically for the outlook to change. I think a culture change will take a lot of time to reshape. Recognize your employees who are working hard and performing well. Stop focusing on layoffs and focus on managing your employees so that you won't have to do layoffs. If you paid well and brought in more high performers, rather than good to average employees, you might not have to consider layoffs.

review_title: Great company, if grueling work isn't an issue
pros: They are an ethical company with an admirable attitude on both environmental issues and employee wellness. They try to give fair pay, be flexible with work/life balance, and are very safety conscious. They atmosphere is very open and low-level employees can work with higher level employees often to gain experience. Also, they do take your long-term goals into consideration.
cons:
Very aggressive on financial goals. This often means understaffing, overworking, mandatory weekends, and cutting funding to certain departments to meet these productivity goals. My department was in a perennial panic mode due to these moving targets, even though we were also very profitable. When interviewing, I would advise probing into how your department is doing as a standard question.
Advice to Management
Understand that possible isn't the same as advisable. The understaffing issues are pervasive and a huge reason I am looking elsewhere. I have never worked in a place that tried to squeeze so much efficiency out of each of its workers.

pros: Work Schedule: M-T 6:00 AM-4:30PM. Nice 3 day weekend. Extremely Easy work for machine operator/packaging. Small bonuses here and there.
cons:
Thought this job would be a great way to start a career. Wow, was I deceived. If you are a Media Production Operator, have fun dealing with the favoritism and sucking up, not to mention the rude and inconsiderate attitude by fellow employees. Management is so uncoordinated and disorganized. The environment I worked in was a complete joke. My position was made for people who wanted to go nowhere in life, or they had no other option due to being a foreigner or having familial obligations, or maybe a combination of both. Unprofessionalism and favoritism were the worst parts to me. And don't get me started on how they love taking advantage of hard working people. I was working on a machine that really needed to be ran by two people, and required more physical energy in one hour than other people in my department put in in their 10 hour shifts. Did management care? I'll leave that up to the imagination. My advice would be to stay away from this place. I got direct hired, however most people must go through a temporary hiring service before they can become full time employees. And who decides when they are worthy? You guessed it: Supervisors. I've seen hard working temporary people take up to 9-12 months to get hired on FT. I've also seen people who love to be buddy buddies with the leads and Supervisors get hired within the minimum time of 3 months. Work here at your own risk, I could go on and on, but this is just the very tip of the iceberg.
Advice to Management
Don't bring your misery and depression to the workplace, leave that at home. And especially don't take it out on your employees who actually think and stand up for themselves.

review_title: Great place to learn - not a long term career
pros: Solid compensation, good benefits, global company that affords an opportunity to learn process development and improvement. Some ability to transfer internally.
cons:
Limited ability to advance without a strong senior advocate. There is absolutely a good old boys club that places a ceiling on people regardless of their abilities. Business processes are often developed and used more to maximize profit than to truly serve the customer. In many divisions/locations, work-life balance is something that is paid lip service and nothing more. The extra hours and effort are seldom rewarded as favoritism is rampant. The compensation diminishes the longer you stay as they do not provide merit increases commensurate with effort or that match pace with cost of living increases.
Advice to Management
Senior management is not appropriately engaged and there are a number of middle management folks that are dreadful. Many rank and file employees have excellent ideas that are routinely ignored or hijacked by local managers to make themselves look better. As a manager myself, it disgusted me to see this happen over and over with no repercussions to the offenders. Many talented folks leave because they are overworked and unappreciated. Come out of the ivory towers for more than a couple of hours and actually talk to people. As a people manager for over a decade, I never once met the CEO or had an opportunity to do so. Very strange way of behaving.

review_title: Tewksbury, MA - PAI not conducive to fult time
pros:
Has a gym and cafeteria, Semi-flexible work hours
Environment is more favorable for contractors - contract durations are always completed 
During the summer, has had 9hr-work days/alternate fridays free
Software Management has good methodologies, is fair, and listens to engineers
Hardware Management follows good methodoligies, is fair and listens. (has since been absorbed into system management)
Easy access from highway, Good life style alternative to fast paced environments, or aggressive startups
During the summer has had 9hr-work days/alternate fridays free
cons:
Office environment and furniture are open, noisy and distinctive 
Upper management is out of touch and in approachable with what and who key contributors and what they do.
Incessant, indiscriminate layoffs. High performers laid off over dead weight.
System management is antiquated and methodologies are backwards. It has a technical veneer. 
Transparency deficiency, and deceit are part of system managements ways of working.
Business unit is hemorrhaging financially 
Documentation isn't maintained and IP leaves the company during layoffs. Requires recreation of IP.
Only sustaining left for engineering, the last two development projects have left for China and India.
Open positions are due to attrition and layoffs. Interviewers should ask why their position is open.
No opportunity for advancement
Advice to Management
Upper management needs to wake up. There is no consciousness about specific values of its
human resources. 

Upper management leaves HR details to lower levels. Causes loss of good/right people.
Hardware management should be separated out from under system management. Hardware management worked well.
System management needs re-org/replacement. Alternatively, do better to just get rid of it.
Seek a different Business Unit for work until management is reorganized.

review_title: Good people, but plagued by consistent systemic problems
pros: Everyone is extremely hard working and courteous. Management listens to employee suggestions and does what they can to help. Big company with a variety of opportunity if you are looking to move laterally
cons:
The company is so big and siloed that poor communication is the norm, not the exception. Tough to get proper visibility and advance, upward mobility is difficult. Most people are overworked and are not properly compensated. Work life balance is becoming more of a problem. Turnover is extremely high in some departments and can be devastating for continuity and employee morale.
Advice to Management
The company is too big to properly fix the communication and advancement issues in my opinion. The only thing you can hope for is to give employees better benefit packages and flexible work schedules to avoid losing top talent.

review_title: Talent acquisition here is a bad place
pros:
Great 401K match
Flexible work arrangements
Career opportunities if you are lucky
cons:
After 5 years with Thermo Fisher, I can say 3.2 rating reflects the Thermo Fisher employee experience. 

The Talent Acquisition organization in Thermo Fisher is a terrible place to be. First, the politics. Lots of gossip flying around every day about who TA's big boss likes, the person she likes seemed to be disliked by everyone else, and how that person likes to hire her own people and get rid of every one that's not her friend. Because people in this TA team likes gossip, you'll soon hear baseless comments/gossip about your work from everyone. 

Apart from the gossip and politics, there is also very little work-life balance. I found myself having to work way more than 9hrs a day to keep the stakeholders happy. 

If you could find a place that's rated higher than Thermo Fisher, then don't come here.

pros: Stock grants. If lucky enough to get them.
cons:
Employees are not valued. Thermo will extract as much from you as possible and then cut you loose. No desire to keep people on based on their history of performance. If you make what the company believes to be a mistake, you are gone.

Don't believe for a second that the company cares about you as an individual. They are profit driven and unless you or your business unit is number one in your market then you are subject to being cut loose. If consistently worrying about your future is what drives you as an individual, then best of luck.
Advice to Management
The only thing that drives this company is share price. Eventually the losses will mount. Customers will find other sources of products and sources. Treating employees as disposable resources does not create a sustainable enterprise. Additionally, stacking Glassdoor with "spam" ratings does not work either.

pros:
1. breadth and quality of products create greater company stability
2. volume of businesses within the company provide diverse career opportunities 
3. products can truly enable the scientific community to improve life for all
4. extensive learning and development opportunities
5. culture of continuous improvement 
6. nice campus in Carlsbad with state of the art fitness center and full service cafe on-site
cons:
1. extremely frugal company (salary, benefits, rewards, budgets)
2. continuously fast paced work environment
3. As with most corporations, employees are continuously required to do more with less--resource constraints make it difficult to deliver the best work
4. poor employee on-boarding
5. contract workforce typically does not often convert to FTE positions, resulting in revolving door of new trainees
6. heavy focus on recruiting and attracting millennials and less-experienced, lower-wage employees
7. not a great deal of ethnic or gender diversity above the director level
8. antiquated employee calibration process rates vast majority of employees at or below standard
Advice to Management
Advocate more strongly for your team resources, challenging the status quo. Consider replacing the current calibration process.

pros: Great people, customer service, HR, quality, manufacturing engineers. Do the best they can to build product that meets customer expectations. Ok benefits.
cons:
Leaderahip has favorites. Inability to grow and develop high performers on your team unless you are one of the chosen few. Director level disfunction - not a cohesive team. Finger pointing and lack of ownership. Nothing will ever change unless you see and own your part and take steps to stop the disfunction.
Advice to Management
Directors-figure out how to launch a succesful product, set reasonable goals, and stick to them! Stop driving unrealestic goals and dates to meet arbitrary metrics that show you are doing the right thing. Customer is affected each and every time you launch a product that is not ready!!! You see this each time it happens!
Celebrate your teams successes rather than continually find fault/opportunities to improve. Support each other and stop finding opportunities to throw each other under the buss.
Management 101.

review_title: Toxic Work Environment and Damaging Culture At Play within Talent Acquisition
pros: Global experience working with the Fortune 500 company
cons:
If you've ever worked for a company with politics at play, you'll know exactly what I am going to say before I say it. Politics eroded and destroyed the high-performing and trusting TA team I was part of within a few years time. It was mostly the doing of one particularly toxic and unfortunate leader, however when leader with these traits are empowered, the rest is history. The leadership of this team have a few blind spots and a survival instinct. . When added together, this combination left members of the team unsupported and craving a leader who had their back. 

I am a firm believer that open and honest communication can soften any news. I also believe that the integrity of the people that you work for matter. I found myself missing these things tremendously at Thermo Fisher. The only exception is when the project you are leading is a priority for the business. When that is the case, you'll be treated well, and moderately rewarded. But when your high priority project is over, so are you. 

There are so many opportunities right now, don't waste your time on Thermo Fisher. If you do take a chance on them, use it for everything it's worth so you don't look back and regret it. 

I do not regret my time with the company, but being on the other side really puts into perspective how toxic and unhealthy the last 2 years were.

pros: I can honestly say there are no pros working for this company
cons:
No room for growth, First company I've ever worked for who doesn't encourage growth, they actually endorse failure, they make it hard to want to come to work, low pay, have to be an expert in many areas but do not compensate, they make it very hard to excell in any area, the praise is given to the same people, month after month, such a slave/master mentality there
-There are a lot people in management who seem to have their jobs purely because of how long they've been at the company (some people are at 10+ years there). In fact, you seem to get many perks just because of your tenure or who you know and how well you know them.
Technology was a bit behind the times
Advice to Management
Management is really a joke. 
A happy employee is a good employee, remember what it was like when you were at the bottom.
Get out of the way, you have smart people working for you, get out of the way.
Focus on employee development as well as the bottom line. Listen to employees and remove roadblocks rather than creating ambiguous or conflicting goal

Work to diversify the management team in terms of gender, ethnicity and experience.
Clean the management house.
Close the doors up, pull your ripcords, whatever. Hopefully Marc Casper sees you for the incompetent "leaders" you are and much like what we need to do with Congress and the Senate, fires EVERYONE

pros: Amazing catalog, phenomenal resources, booming market and great team of people
cons:
new sales strategies from leadership leave the sales teams feeling highly micromanaged and demotivated. Constantly changing the sales team product bag due to frantic acquisition rate makes it difficult to be a resource to customers and feeds into the negative reputation as the "walmart of science". Recent trends in company policy lead staff to feel more like members of a cold mega corporation instead of a cutting edge big company with a small company personal feel.
Advice to Management
Cut down on dictating blanket policies left and right to the staff and empower your leadership teams to make their own decisions about how to run their districts. Renew an emphasis on rewarding hard work and giving your employees room to be creative as opposed to looking for ways to cut down costs at every corner. Streamline your offerings and create sales strategies for your teams before making massive acquisitions and haphazardly throwing enormous product offerings on to your staff. Come down from the tower and see your teams operate in the trenches, ask for and pursue genuine feedback aggressively.

location: São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo
review_title: Every Thermo Fisher Site is Different
pros: Overall, the company is a powerhouse. You will be a part of a monopoly-type company that will continue to grow while absorbing it's smaller competitors. Careers can be built here, and the positions are long term and safe.
cons:
As stated in the title, every Thermo Fisher Site is operated independently. My review is for my specific site in Fremont, California. Here at this site, the company grew too fast and the business model and technology could not keep up with the growth. Since the site is operating at a pre-historic pace, while trying to keep up with the industry expectations, this results in long stressful hours and absolutely no work/life balance. To top it off, the salaries do not compete with the current market, but i do hear that management is trying to adjust accordingly based off the current market.
Advice to Management
Instead of trying to monopolize the market and force your employees to keep up with growth we do not have the tools and resources for, let's stabilize what we are currently producing and focus on providing a higher quality level of service while delivering to the customer 100% on-time.
